Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished this for you, O Children, a book which is the last knowledge in medicine with its completion, and I have reached the end of it through its explanations and its declarations, it was my wish to complete it for you with this treatise which is a part of the operation, that is, chirugery with my hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Because the operation with the hand is laid low in our region and completely cut off: until perhaps science of it perishes, and its track is abolished: and they do not remain except brief descriptions in ancient books, which have changed their hands: and an error and hesitation happen to them until their intentions are closed, and the length of its will is elongated: It seemed good to me to enliven it with the life of this treatise in it according to the way of position and declaration and abbreviation: and to make it like the forms of the Cauteries and other instruments of work: when an addition is made to the declaration, and the operation of its being necessary is performed.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	However, the cause why this good craftsman did not find it with his hand in our time is: because medicine is long, and it is necessary for the author to exercise before that in the knowledge of anatomy which Galen narrated, until he knows the humors of the members, and their forms, and their connection, and their separation, and has knowledge of bones, and nerves, and tendons, and the number of them, and their exit, and the pulsatility and quietness, and the exits of their places:
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And therefore Hippocrates said that the name with the name is much, and with the work is little, and especially in the art of the hand:
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	But we have already spoken of that at the beginning of this book:
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Because he who is not knowledgeable of what I say about anatomy does not understand, but already falls into error, wherein men are slain: as I have seen many of them, who are formed from this science, and cast it aside without knowledge, and without experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	That which is, because I have seen a stupid physician cut the abscess of a woman's neck, and some arteries were cut in her neck: therefore blood flowed from the woman until she died at his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another physician, who presumed to extract a stone from a boy who had grown up, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore he went to him, and extracted it with a small instrument.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	And the boy died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	Indeed I had called to extract it myself: and I saw from the greatness of the stone, and the weakness of the position, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another physician, who received a stipe from a certain Duke of our land for medicine: and it happened to an eunuch black man, who was near the heel of his wrist, and he broke: and the physician, not knowing his own ignorance, struck the fracture with his thumb over the ulna with pulsars, and strong bows, and did not release the wound's expiration.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he released him according to his desire.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Later he released him for days, and warned him not to loosen the bandage: and he stood thus until the abscess of his foot was out, and his own leg, and he called for death.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I am called to him: and I came to loosen the bandage: and peace followed, and he was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	Indeed, corruption had already been confirmed in the member and I could not halt it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	When corruption ceased to walk in the member, it has now perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who had pierced an epidermoid cancer: the ulcer has worsened over days until his malice was fully revealed to the lord of it.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	What this means is that when the cancer is pure from the melancholic fluid, it does not need to be treated with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can tolerate it, so that the entirety of it can be amputated.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, O Son, it is necessary for you to know that the operation is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation associated with safety, and the operation with which there is danger in many arrangements.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already stirred up the entirety of this book, in which the operation comes where there is terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to guard against this, and let it go: so that foolish people may not find it to speak, and to dishonor.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, take the measure with anxiety and protection, and your weakness with ease and firmness, and use it as a better means of salvation and praiseworthy succession by the grace of God: and let go of difficult-to-heal terrifying afflictions, and remove your spirits from that which makes you fear, so that it may come upon you a doubt in your faith and comfort.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining for your glory, and sublime in this world, and finally for your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat illness with evil: do not call physicians bad.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	However, this treatise is divided into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter first.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter on cauterization with fire and sharp-edged medicine, divided into sections from the head to the feet, and descriptions of the tools and instruments of cauterization, and all that is necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter second.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Chapter on sections and piercings, bloodletting and venting, and wounds: and the removal of arrows and similar, and all the chapter is divided into forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter third.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Chapter on restoration, and dislocation, and curing of twisting, and similar: the chapter is divided from the head to the feet, and descriptions of the tools and instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory to God alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the use of cauterization and its effects, and which complexions are suitable, and at what time, and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	However, before that, it is necessary to say about the quality of the wounds and the effects of cauterization of his own: and in which complexion it will be shown.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say that the speech about the quality of cauterization and its effects is a long and subtle one, knowledge, and a secret and hidden science.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Even many wise men have spoken about it, and they have disputed about it, and for me it is enough a little from their words, fearing the extension.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say that cauterization is effective against all wounds, whether with matter or without matter, except for two wounds: the hot wound without matter and the dry wound without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, in the hot and dry wound with matter, they differ.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some have said that cauterization is in the hot and dry wound with matter.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	However, others have said that cauterization is not suitable for the disease which is from heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat: and it is unsuitable to heal from a hot and dry disease with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite has said that by cauterization a wound is made in all hot and dry disease that occurs in the bodies of humans: for when you compare the body of a man and its humors to the fire, you will find the body of a man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	I myself say by his words: because I have already experienced this by experiment.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	Nevertheless, it does not belong for him to come upon that, unless he who has already proved it, and has been exercised in the chapter of cauterization, and has known the diversity of human complexions, and the disposition of diseases in themselves, and their causes, and accidents, and the space of time of theirs.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	However, there is no fear from the rest of the complexions: and especially in cold and humid diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have come to them, and they have not differed in the wound with cauterization in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And you know, O sons, that by the secret of the curing with Cauterization with fire, and the goodness of it over the medicine burning with Cauterization is: for fire is simple, whose action does not affect anything except to the member which is cauterized, and does not hurt another member connected with it, unless it hurts a little.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of burning surgeons in medicine is directed towards that which is extended from the limbs: and perhaps it causes difficulty in the treatment of difficult disease in a member, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	However, fire, because of its own subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do this unless it is superfluous.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed, we have learned this by experiment, because of the length of the servitude and study with the art, and the station above the truth of things: and for that reason I excuse the length of the speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if there were not, because it is not allowed for this book of mine to bring you the secret, hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies, by which it expels diseases that are demonstrated in the philosophical speech, which is disturbed by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And do you know, sons, that you yourself dissent in the time when it is fitting to make the cauterization, and you set a better time for the lesson.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cauterization is fitting in every time, because the harm done by the time is swallowed up in the wound, which is attracted by the cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And above all, if the cauterization is made for necessary pains, which are hard, urgent, which do not endure delay: for that reason, because it is feared that a greater evil may happen than the small harm that is done by the time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And it will not fall into your sons' minds that this is not true, unless they are foolish and stupid physicians, namely that the diseases which are cured by cauterization are not always a return: and they set this as a consequence, and the thing is not as they think: for cauterization is not but in the place of medicine, which alters the complexion, and dries up the humors which are causes of the pains, therefore the pains happen.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Indeed, cauterization benefits the patient's health, its own virtue, and the vigor of his dominion. It is possible that the illness leaves for a certain period of time according to the complexion of the weak, and the location of the patient's illness, and the virtue of his illness. And that it is prepared in the body of him from the aggregation of superfluities in him. And that it is sated with it in its acquisition from foods, and similar ones from like causes, unless an illness occurs, in which the cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle illness in the member of a few superfluities and moistures, like the cauterization of teeth, for pain, and such like, is possible that it does not remain in that pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that happens in few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But that speech is a true saying: not to what they intend in it: for they believe that there is no cure which confers with the medicine, nor with another after the occasion of the cauterization.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the case is opposite to that, and the intention, that cauterization is the last of the medicines, is not, unless when we administer modes of cure in some illnesses, and they do not conform to the medicine: then we administer the cauterization at the end of the disease, and it conforms: then it falls out that cauterization is the last of the medicines, not according to the intention which wise and experienced physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But the ancients said that cauterization with gold is better than with iron: and they did not say this except for the equality of gold, and the sublimity of its own substance: and they said that it does not make a pus in the place of the cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	Indeed, that is not entirely true: for I have already proven that, and found that it does not make that in certain bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cauterization, when used alone, is good, and better than when iron is used, as they say.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you use fire for cauterization on gold, it is not declared to you when it is heated according to the amount you wish, because of the redness of the gold: and when it approaches the cold, and if you add more heat to it, it melts in the fire and turns into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the artisan falls away from that occupation: and therefore cauterization is made with iron among us, more easily and nearer, due to the straightness to the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have indeed ordered this chapter on cauterization, according to the chapter: and I have ordered them from the head down to the feet: so that they may be sought by those who wish to find out what is in it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	¶ About the method of cauterizing the head in a circular cut.
Caput II.	Head 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterization is applied to the mastery of moisture and coldness over the head: which are two causes of salt, and the multitude of fluids from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and the multitude of dreams, and pain of teeth, and pain of the throat: and generally all kinds of disease that happen from coldness, such as paralysis, and salt, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and similar ones from those diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is to apply it to the weak: so that it may be emptied in the beginning with the dissolved medicine of the head three or four nights, according to the strength of the infirm, and their age, and their habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then he commanded him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit down between your hands, squarely, so that he has already placed his own hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the palm of your hand over his nose, between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Therefore, if the middle finger of your hand touches it, mark the place with a sharp point.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the olive-oil cauterization: whose form this is.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it directly on the marked place with a sharp point, gradually drawing your hand together, and you will roll it over.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly pull back your hand, and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see already that you can cut off the amount of the skull or the amount of the bone, then pull back your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with iron itself, or with another that is frozen, until the bones that I told you about are seen.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take something from the salt, dissolve it in water, drink it yourself, and place it on the spot, and leave it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the buttermilk drunk on top of it over the place, and leave it there until the scar burns out with fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with Tetrapharmacons ointment, until it is cured.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	Now they have said that as more of the gash remains open, pus is released: therefore it is better and more inflamed.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that it should be cauterized to the bone, and hold the cauterization until it becomes thick with some density of bones.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it is shaved after that which has been made thick from the bone, and then it is cured.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	When others say that it is necessary to cauterize up to the end, so that an impression of the iron is made on the lip, in such a way that the lip falls off, as if it were a bone: or when women use an instrument infused with certain alphabets, they think that vapors arise from this place of the head, and the gum becomes loose for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it is treated, until it is solidified.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	I do not recognize these two kinds of cauterization at all, except in some men according to their fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And to let it go, in my opinion, is better with the health of the patient.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head weakens from the solution of its own continuous nature, as we have testified in other parts of the body: and especially when the head is feeble and weak in nature: and the first kind of cauterization is indeed safer and better with me, and I use it: therefore, to operate with this in health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	¶ About the mode of cauterizing the head in the pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	¶ The Head (III).
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When there is a chronic pain throughout the head, and it lasts in the feeble, and uses leeches, and needles, and head pills, and oils, and plasters:
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with the iron we have mentioned, and nothing benefits it from these: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head is weak from a strong nature of creation, and it is not feeble, and it finds cold weather: then cauterize with another iron less than that.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over the whole of its own head with the iron, and do not pierce the skin, and do not cut through the quantity of bone which we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	He should cauterize himself with a single burn on the back of his head, in the place known as the 'vagina'. This is the place where the wind is produced, and he should cut away the hair of his face, and not neglect the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For he is weak because of this painful grief, and it differs from the pain of other head cauteries.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say this: and it is necessary that this be the cauterization in its place: and it should be the cauterization whereby the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of his head with a softer cauterization, whereby the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is the form of him.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	¶ About the method of cauterization in migraine, both when the medicine is inflamed and when it is made of iron.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and swelling occur in a part of the head, or it extends to the eye, and the face becomes moist with the application of medicines, and the rest of the treatment is given as I said in the divisions of illness, and it does not fit all of this: then the cauterization in him is of two kinds: either with hot medicine burning: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But when the cauterization is with hot medicine burning, it is like this: take a tooth from another person, and encircle it, and cut off the ends of its sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then divide the place of pain when the phlebitis is wide, until there is a place under the skin where the tooth can be caught.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then insert it into the same place under the skin until it is hidden: then tie it around with a suitable string, and release it after fifteen hours, then extract the tooth, and remove the almond, and leave it for two or three days, or four: then place a submerged belly over the place, until the place produces pus: then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	If you wish to perform this with certain drugs that I have written about in the twelfth book of the Medicine, which are used for the purpose of causing abortion.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization of it with iron is done in this way.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The cauterization is made by fire, which has this form.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called the Claudian: for its head-form is like that of a claw, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle there is a small prominence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it directly on the spot and hold your hand there: and you will grind the iron with great violence, as much as is necessary from the thickness of the skin, just as the middle part of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And scrape your hand with it, so that the artery below is not burned and the flow of blood is prevented.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then drink the poultice in salt water, and place it on the spot for three days, then place the poultice with honey, and afterwards care for it with ointment until it is cured.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, you can cauterize this half-head with the second point of the cauterization.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And be careful not to cut the artery in this half-head, properly speaking.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	¶ In the method of cauterizing in an old half-head.
Caput V.	¶ Head 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are treating a half-head, with what I have said in the treatment preceding it, and with what I have said about divisions of diseases, and not with the cure: and you see from the disease that it is not enough for him that I have said with the first cauterization with medicine, or with cauterization with fire, then it is necessary to make the cauterization with the second point of the cauterization, until it becomes white after the signs on the spot of pain with the line, whose length is the middle of the digit, or as if this were: and place your hand on it, one by one, and tie it until you cut the artery, and peruse up to the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	Indeed, it is necessary for you to prevent the continuation of the jaw, which moves during chewing, from becoming inflamed on the side, or the nerve that moves it, from causing a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And this is for the care of the jaw, and as a precaution against the flow of the arterial blood, which has been severed.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	In the process of removal, there is fear, and especially for those who do not know what is being done, nor are willing, nor experienced: and they let the operation be with him at the beginning.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I remember with the regulation of the flow of blood from the artery according to its own mode, and in the place of this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the patient's illness, that the caustic is not sufficient for him, and you see a weak body enduring the caustic in the middle of the head, as we have mentioned, take care of the gum, until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, apply the caustic that we said in the chapter of the removal of the artery with two hammers.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more beneficial.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	§ About the method of cauterizing in pain of the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain in the ear comes from cold, and is cured with the dissolution of the ice, and the rest of the treatment that we have mentioned in the division, and the pain is not removed, then apply fire cauterization: and this is what is called the Punctum, whose form is as follows.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then make the punctures with it after its ignition around the ear, as it rotates: or around the entire circumference if the pain is in both at the same time.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And stretch the ear with the cauterization from the root of the ear almost immediately after you see the places that are on fire with the caustic: and the quantity of the cauterization should be ten punctures in the entire ear, and as it were that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then take care of the place until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	¶ In method of cauterization in torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Torture which is performed with cauterization, is none other than those species which happen from phlegm, according to what we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And he divided the species of cauterization which happens from dryness, and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you are treating this species of torture with ointments, and purgatives, and gargles, and your cure does not benefit, then it is necessary to cauterize the weak one with three cauterizations: one at the root of the ear, and another a little lower than at its time, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cauterization from the opposite side of the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not happen, except in the part which appears to be healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is, that it cauterizes itself with Cauterization in direct position at the upper part of the ear, under the horn of the head, a little: and another at its time: whose length is according to the length of the finger.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And put down your hand with the cauterization, until the quantity of the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of cauterization, and it is a species from the penknife, whose form we have mentioned: verily it is not too thin, as you see: and it is necessary that the penknife be in it with too much bulk.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place when that which precedes has been done, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	¶ In method of cauterization in old stroke.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes old, and when you treat it as we said, and your treatment does not agree with it, and it does not have a fever, then cauterize it with four caustics on all the crown of its head, and a caustic in the middle of its head, as we said, and a caustic in the back of its head, according to what precedes: and the mode of cauterization should be according to what precedes.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Even it is cauterized with a caustic over the top of the stomach's mouth, and it is the last of all.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is treated, according to what precedes.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	¶ About the mode of cauterization in oblivion.
Caput IX.	Head, number nine.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that they be given in the first place to a weak hypersensitive large hair, and pills that cleanse the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the weak head entirely, and put on top of its occiput the plaster described in the treatise on plasters: and put it on several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For the plaster itself is the mode of cauterization: and make it according to the same order that we said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If then it is cured by this, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then give it three caustics in the back of its head, which are descending from the top of its head to the lower part of the eye: and put between all the caustic a size of the digit.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the caustic according to what precedes.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you want an addition, and it is enduring that, then give it a caustic in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you want an addition: then cauterize it on two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat it, until it is cured: and the caustic should be olive-colored according to the form that we said before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterization in paralysis and mollification.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed with the cleaning of the head with hot water and as said before.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then rub the weak head: then cauterize it with cauterization in the middle of the head, and with cauterization over all the crown, and with cauterization over the posterior part of it, and three over the spine of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	However, if you need more than one cauterization for the mollification of the body, and the patient tolerates it well, and the disease is strong: then cauterize it with four cauterizations over the spine of the back, and the last one with cauterization until it burns most of its skin, and use your hand to peel it off.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then take care of it until it heals: and then apply olive oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterization in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	Epilepsy is not cauterized unless it belongs to someone with a phlegmatic epilepsy.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, it is necessary to clean the head of his brain first with hot water and as said before with the rest of the care that I mentioned in division, when he is weak or tolerates in acceptance of the medicine.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	However, if the child is one who does not tolerate medicines, then a gargle and mastications are given to clean the head of his brain before that days with many good foods.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then rub his head, then cauterize it with one cauterization in the middle of the head, according to how it precedes in the way: and with another cauterization on the back of his head, and over all the crown of his own cauterization.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	That if he is weak but tolerates it well, then cauterize him with the cauterizations I said in having paralysis and mollification of the body over the spine of the neck, and over the spine of the back: and let the olive oil be a cauterization according to the way that precedes.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If then the boy is weak, place a fine cauterium at that time. So.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterization in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the causes of melancholy are corrupt humors and a gross phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries we have mentioned for paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is superfluous humors that turn to melancholy, and the body is a moist one, then give it power to cleanse its brain according to what precedes in division: then shave the head of the infirm one, and afterward make a decent tortellum from linen, as a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it on the middle of the head: and the infirm one sitting squarely is held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more suitable from ancient honey.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a tempered fire with the measured heat of the fingers, when it is inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of its head in a circle, and release it until it is hardened.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this to the weak one once a week, with the good rule of the remaining, until it is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you will, cauterize it by making small points on it as much as possible, besides holding the hand with the cauterization, and let it be fragrant.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this species of cauterization moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it the drunk one that has swallowed the honey or goose fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	Chapter XIII. On the method of cauterization in descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When I declare to you the beginning of water in the eye through the signs which I said in division, then begin to drink the weak water, with that which cleanses its head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard it from all moistures, and make it sit in the bath for a few days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to shave his head and burn it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him twice over, if the descent of water is delayed in both eyes at once: or from one side, if it is delayed in one eye: and cut off all the veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in breadth: and beware of the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see something from it, then cut him off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I am like with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting, and caution of the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is cauterized in the hair, under two bones, with the last two cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	¶ About the way of cauterizing in ancient tears.
Caput XIIII.	Head XIII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and frequent: and they are over the veins, and the arteries which are in the manifest skin of the head: it is believed that this is from superfluous cold, and phlegmatic: then cauterize with the same cauterization that I will tell you about the delay of water descending, with cauterization in the middle of the head, and two cauteries over two times, and two cauteries in the hair under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need an addition, then cauterize it on all sides of the eye, with a small cauterization at the end of the eyebrow.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	In a similar manner, cauterization is performed on the beard of the nose.
Caput XV.	Head XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating this, if the division is as we have said and there is no need for medication, then immediately give three doses of the ointment to an impoverished patient: then shave the head of the patient and cauterize it with a medium-sized cauterizing iron, using olive oil.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with the cauterizing iron using two cauterizing irons, over two above the eyebrows, under the very short hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, do not set it on fire.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the form of Clauilis cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	In a similar manner, cauterization is performed on the eyelid for smoothing.
Caput XVI.	Head XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid is smoothed by disease or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cauterizing iron, using the moon-shaped cauterizing iron.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows with two cauterizing irons in all parts: and they will elongate in two intervals: and the length of the cauterization should be according to the length of the eyebrows, and not finally your hand with the cauterizing iron, even according to the amount that becomes third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of cauterization according to this method of lunar cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	In a similar manner, cauterization is performed on the eyelid when the hairs become rough and painful in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Head XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cauterizing iron in this is according to two methods: either with fire, or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In cauterization with fire, you should advise the patient beforehand to let go of his hairs, if he has them shaved, until they grow out and become longer.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If, however, they prick him at his own point: then bind his eyes with thread, so that they may not move, until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are born and turn, then place the weak head in the fold of your garment: then make a sign on the eyelids of his eyes with a candle, a sign that is according to the figure of the myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the sign be near the hair.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a drunken mouth on the aliment: or on the eye with a silk mucilage.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then burn the cauterization, whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the figure which you have gradually marked on many skin folds, until the surface of the skin is completely burned, which is like the figure of the myrtle leaf, in its entirety.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of your healing work is: if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting, and the hair being plucked at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then pluck out your hand: and let it be three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place a drunken mouth on the aliment with honey, until the scar is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any hair remains after the hour, and the eyelid becomes soft: then repeat the cauterization on that place, as you have done at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If the hairs are at the bottom: then cauterize it itself, until the hair becomes to its natural place, and is equal to not pricking the eye with a hair.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	¶ About the method of cauterizing when the medicine is burning in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	¶ Head 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is as if you were making a weak man free, until the hairs grow out and become long.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	The shape of the leaves of the myrtle tree on a sheet of paper.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from the soap known, and from the unsoaked shoe, one ounce of weight, or almost the same: then dry it together with good contrition, and make it with haste, so that it does not fail.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from the pan and place it on the sheet of paper you made, like the shape of the myrtle leaf, and place it directly on the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a wet morsel, and make the weak head sit in your groove.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	Then place your finger on the medicine and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And move it as often as the weak feels the medicine's sting, for its sting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While he persisted in this which he found to be the sting, then let him release the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the sting has ceased, then remove the medicine, and wash out the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider if you see the eyelid swelling up, as it does when contracting with fire or with incision, and that is good: and if not, then try again on the same spot of the medicine, until the operation of your hand has equalized and the eye has contracted.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place the wet morsel on top of it, until the scaly skin is burned away.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment or other, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during the operation to keep the last watch, so that nothing falls out of the medicine into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	That is if the eyelid becomes softened after a day, and something falls out of the hair into the eye, then try the medicine again on the same spot that was softened from the eyelid properly, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it itself until it is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you know that the eyes of humans are diverse in size and proportions.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to this, your consideration is: and the straightness of his desire for this art is not concealed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	¶ About the method of cauterizing in the tear duct.
Caput XIX.	Head 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you are treating the tear duct fistula, when as we said in the division of diseases, and your treatment does not agree with it: then, it is necessary for you to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Please make the patient place his head in your groove, and hold his head gently between his hands in this way, so that it does not move, nor does he move with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place the injected cotton in the corner of the eye, or in the silica gel above his eye: then heat the cauterization, whose form is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be thin, as the desired form of the pen of a quill wants to be from one end, with which the cauterization is made: and if you want it to pass through to the other end, and if you want it to be upward, then try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this thinness is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and take out the healthy part from it, and scrape it: and if it is not open, then open it, and take out the pus of it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place then on it the cauterization that is made hot gently.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold it with your hand as little as possible near the cauterization, from the eye to the nose, so that your hand does not slip, or become weak: and place the cauterization in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If then the skin is thoroughly wet at the beginning of the cauterization until the mouth, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then you will repeat the cauterization once, or twice, if you need it: and let that one be for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place the ointment with honey, and care for it with the dried ointment, until it is cured.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If more than forty days pass and it does not heal: then place on top of it sharp medicine for corrosion, until the mouth is exposed: and tear it off according to what comes in the chapter of its kind.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterization fistula, which some of the first ones said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Consider to the place of the fistula and find it: then place in its own narrow slit a thin cannula, which is called the thin cannula, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour in it a quantity of drachm of melted lead, and hold your hand with good retention of the cannula, and do not tremble at all, so that it does not run, or flow melted lead to its eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to put on top of the weak eye honey-infused ointment in albumen or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For the lead burns the place of the fistula and cures it by a miraculous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, with what we said from cauterization and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to apply the nostril and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what it wants in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	¶ About the method of cauterization in the splits of the Lips.
Caput XX.	Head 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many happen in the lip, which are called hairs, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you treat these fissures, when you consider what we said about division of diseases, and the treatment does not help, then a small cauterization tool, in this form, should be used.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And its connection should be according to the fineness of the tool.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the heated rod immediately in the same fissures, until the cauterization tool reaches the deep fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with care, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	¶ Method of cauterization in the mouth fistula.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When aphthae occur in the root of the gingiva, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus, and bursts: afterwards it becomes dry, and the pus runs, and forms a fistula: then treat the fistula itself, and do not let the treatment help in it: then it is necessary to use heated cauterization tool according to the amount that is taken in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the heated tool into the fistula opening, and hold your hand, until the heated iron reaches the deepest part of it, and finally its: do this once or twice more.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it afterwards, when we said about the treatment until it heals.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If then the pus is cut off and it heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to expose the place and remove the rotten bone according to what does not want in its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	¶ Method of cauterization in gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When ginger is softened due to moisture, and teeth are moved, and it is treated with medicines, and does not fit: then place the weak head in your side groove.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then make a cauterization, whose form will be as hot as this afterward, so that you can place the Cannula over the tooth: and quickly insert the hot cauterization into it: and hold your hand for a moment, until the weak tooth feels that the heat of the fire has reached its root.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And scrape your hand: then repeat the cauterization as many times as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then fill the weak mouth with salt water, and hold it for an hour: and spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened, and the softened ginger is tied up, and dried out the moist corruption.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	¶ About the method of cauterization in tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Caput XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When tooth pain is due to coldness, or there is coldness in the tooth itself, or frost, and the treatment does not fit with medicines: then the cauterization is in the tooth itself in two ways: either with grease, or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But the cauterization of it with grease is such that you take grease with vinegar, and boil it in a heated iron or in a mortar.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take the fire, and wrap it around the end of the tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then dip it in the boiled grease: and place it over the painful tooth as soon as possible, and hold it until it strengthens: then repeat it several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, dip the wool, or the fire in cold grease, and place it over the painful tooth: and place a hot iron over it until the heat of the fire reaches the deep part of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization of this is when the fire is, as you intend to the copper tube or the iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And there should be some bulkiness in its body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not pierce the weak mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then place the cauterization on the fire, whose form is to be avoided: and put it over the tooth of the light: and hold your hand firmly until the cauterization is stuck.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be removed, either on that same day, or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary in the impression of that cauterization, that the weak mouth fills its own good tooth, and holds it for an hour: then it will spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterization.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whatever extremity you wish, according to what is possible: and this is the form of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	¶ About the method of cauterizing in Strophuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Head XXIV.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the Strophuli are from phlegm, and from cold moisture, and are not obeying the digestions by means of my drugs, and you wish to speed up their digestion: then place the cauterization on fire, whose form is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends, so that the smoke can go by the cauterization at the other end: and put the burning one over the first apostema, and secondly, if you need it, until it pierces the deep apostema.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the apostema is small: then put the cauterization according to the size of the apostema.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let it be three days, and put over it a dough that has been infused with honey on the butyron, until what has burned by the fire is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then he treats the teeth itself with ointment until the form of the canula is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	In the method of cauterization in saliva, and the constriction of sore throat.
Caput XXV.	Head XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the moisture is removed from the lungs, and especially when it is with cold complexion, then it is necessary that the weak one be emptied first with the help of soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then he cauterizes it himself in the throat at the root of the gullet in a depressed hollow: and beware that when using Cauterization on the gullet, nor in the skin, unless some of it.
