Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then he cauterizes it himself with another at the joint of the neck at the end of the spine of its end: and the Cauterization should be a clamp according to the mode that precedes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then he treats it with what follows until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	In the method of cauterization in lung diseases and throat.
Caput XXVI.	Head XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When Tussis and lung disease are caused by cold moisture, and the weak one does not have a fever, nor phthisis, nor old age: then cauterize it with two Cauterizations above the gizzard in depressed locations, soft, and wet.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another Cauterization in the middle of the chest between the two breasts: and the Cauterization should be a canula according to the mode that precedes.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you want your Cauterization to be piercing with the Cauterization called Punctum, which has the form that precedes in the pain of the ear: and let there be thirty piercings at least until another.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then he treats it with what follows until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And already there is a cauterization with three branches, according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Why should the patient be anesthetized when you make the cauterization with one of three Cauterias?
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	In the method of cauterizing in the elbow, in the dislocation of the shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Head 25.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the thumb is dislocated due to humidity and is not marked in the hour of its return to its place, until it becomes familiar with the relocation, then it should be dislocated by a small movement that we have already reported, then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the weak one will return on his back or on the sound side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then peel off the skin that is on the inside of the elbow with the fingers of your left hand and, if it is tied to the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then heat the cauterization with two veru.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates it to the other side and makes the figure of the cauterization with four Cauterias.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes a cauterization is made with a Cauteria having three veru, why does the figure of the cauterization become six Cauterias? And they are veru according to the fineness of the attempt.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of the Cauteria having three veru.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes an additional one is added to this mode, why are there eight Cauterias?
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place on the Cauteria contrited thighs with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make it stick to the weakness in calmness, so that the member does not move at any time, until it is relieved.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is to the upper part and this rarely happens, then it should be cauterized on the shoulder with the closed Cauteria or by many points of the Cauterias.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	The incision is reinforced, and moisture is removed: and the weak is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	In the manner of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Head 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When a cold and much moisture occur in the stomach, until it be taken out of its covering, and catarri be multiplied to it, and constant methods of care be used, and it do not agree: then it is necessary for the weak to be raised on the back of its own body, and its legs extended, and its hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then it is to be cauterized with three cauteries, the first with the breadth of a finger's tip under the cochlear pectoris, and two with the cauteries on either side of the same cauterius, until the figure of the cauteries becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And elongate them between each other, when they do not unite, when they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cauterization should be that of two third parts of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And the figure of the cauterization should be according to this form, without addition: and if you will cauterize with a large cauterization in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and the cauterium by which this is made should be one according to the figure of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is to be cauterized by pointing it with that which fears this cauterization: and it is, that signs on the stomach are made according to the quantity which you will use when you encauter: then the stomach is to be cauterized with the point of cauterization: then care for it with the care which precedes until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	In the manner of cauterizing the epar cold.
Caput XXIX.	Head 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When cold and pain occur in the epar from frigidity and moisture, until it is forced out of its natural covering above excessive emission, and the weak is cared for with it as I said, and it does not succeed in that: then it is necessary for the weak to be raised on the gown of its own body, and signs to be made with three cauteries according to this figure, and the same quantity below the hypocundrii, where the man's thigh is wetted: and there should be a space between every cauterization according to the thickness of the finger: and the cauterization should be according to the length of the body: and do not compress your hand with the cauterization much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	The strength of its application depends on the thickness of the skin, not on the middle part of the body, and it is weak when standing on its own feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If it is not standing, then it is lying down, whose legs have already extended, and has raised its arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cauterization.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you to apply this cauterization with a sharp and skillful hand when you are present with the necessary subtlety and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And take care that you do not finally reach the cauterization, and that the thickness of the skin is spread throughout the body, because it then touches the intestines. For the skin is there very thin, so you know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	Regarding the method of applying the cauterization to the Epbetum.
Caput XXX.	Head 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When the exit occurs, and you want to know if it is an apostemata in the flesh of the Epbetum, or in its tunic, then if it is in the flesh of the Epbetum, it causes a weak pain and stupor without acuity: and if it is in the tunic of the Epbetum, with pain there is acuity of the wound: and you see now that the fatigue of its cure has exhausted the physicians.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, it must be that the weak one lies down on its own pillow.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the place of the apostemata with the cauterization, and then the hot iron that resembles the hand.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And apply the cauterization with that one iron until the whole skin is burned, and it touches the siphac, until all the pus escapes: then care for the cure of the exits until it is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	It is not appropriate to use this cauterization method unless the student's interest in medical arts extends beyond this stage, and if the hands of those who participate in these ailments with experimentation do so repeatedly: for then they will dare to supervise such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	I would rather release it myself, as there is better for you at my place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	In the method of cauterization in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that cauterization with the roots of Aristolochia, applied to the cold pleurisy, according to this method.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is said that you should receive from the dry long roots of Aristolochia, one longer root, which is found in it, and it should be as large as the size of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil, and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cauterization in the middle of the joint where the neck is, and two cauterizations a little below it, towards the part that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And by two cauterizations also in the part that is between the fifth and sixth ribs, leaning towards the posterior: and one cauterization in the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And by three cauterizations from the back: one in the part that is between two spoons: and two cauterizations on the two sides of the chest, with the lower one being between two spoons.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not appropriate to hold your hand with the cauterization, rather it should be in clear skin that smells.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And the ancients have already said that some people use cauterization from metal similar to this: and they light it, and insert it into the part that is between the ribs, until it reaches the apostema with it, and it exudes pus: as we said in the case of Epatis.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	In this perforation with cauterization, there is fear that either the weak one will die immediately, or it happens at the place of the fistula where there is no cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	The method of cauterizing the spleat head (spleen) is described in section XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you heal the sickness of the spleen, when you have said that from the cure in division of diseases, and not because your treatment is not agreeable to it, then cauterization in it is according to three methods, which are all right.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of them is that you make three cauterizations, or four lineations according to the length of the spleen according to the figure of the Ephesian cauteries, whose figure precedes.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let the quantity of every cauterization be equal to the size of the thumb, or more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the method of cauterization that we have said in the Ephesian cauterization be equal.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not compress your hand with cauterization: and let the weak one be supple on its back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	Another method of cauterization is: that with two fires, which we have said in the chapter of dislocation of the shoulder: and let the eleua cut the skin that is in direct to the spleen, where the weak side of the left thigh becomes wet: and let your eleua be such that the cauterization falls according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two burned sticks gently, until they pass through the skin from the other part: then withdraw the cauterization: and thus four cauterizations are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with a cauterization that has three sticks,
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then let you care for the cauterization after you have released it to emit pus for many days: for it is more agreeable than the rest that has preceded from the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	In the method of cauterization in hydropiths.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cauterization does not fall into Hydropiths, unless the points are properly punctured.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are treating Hydropthic wounds according to the methods we have mentioned in division and the cure is not taking, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauterizations around the umbilicus, and one on the stomach, another on the liver, and a third on the spleen, and two after the back between the spinae, and one in the direct direction of the chest, and another in the direct direction of the stomach: and the depth of the cauterization should be proportional to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then allow the open cauterization to emit pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not send away the patient too soon after the cauterization, because it is necessary for two intentions to gather around him: and he will hasten towards cure with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cauterization when it is made in the belly should be a glove: according to which form precedes its own: and its form when it is made on the back should be an olive according to which form precedes it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	In the method of cauterization of feet and limbs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When the wounds are dressed in Hydropthic and filled with citrine water, it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot in the nail, which is between the auricle and the ring: and you should use your hand with the cauterization and do not twist it: then use your hand again: and do not touch it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the citrine water will remain, and the cauterization should be in this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two burns on both legs all over, and make a cauterization at the end of the sword's handle; and make the cauterization according to the length of the leg, one under the knee, and one below it, about in the middle of the leg: and then make two cauterizations on all the thighs: and let the open cauterization remain without long care: so that some water remains from it: then care for it with the rest as I have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	¶ In the manner of cauterizing in the womb fluid.
Caput XXXV.	Caput XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the womb fluid is melted and moistened, until the firming and digesting virtues in the stomach and intestines are weakened: and it is cared for according to the methods of curing, and is not healed: and you see the firm enduring the excessive virtue of the strong virtues, then cauterize it with a large cauterization over the stomach, according to what preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with the circular cauterization, and four small cauterizations around the navel, with a small cauterization subtle: and a cauterization over the alcatin above the alhosos with a large one, or two small ones.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see the excessive moistures and the firm enduring it, then cauterize it with a cauterization over the pectoral muscle, and a cauterization over all of it: and perhaps add two small cauterizations near the large one in the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For this is a curing that does not err in its ingredient.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	¶ In the manner of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Caput XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When in the anus there are old hemorrhoids many, or one, and they are of large humors, cold, or corrupted moistures, and are cured according to what I said in division, and is not a concurring curing: then cauterize it with three cauterizations over the lower spine of the back subtly triangular, and a cauterization under the navel as if two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If you think that the stomach of this animal is frozen, and its food does not digest, and you see its face swelling, then cauterize it over the stomach with a large cauterization iron, according to what precedes: also cauterize over the spleen, and another over the liver of the same animal, with the cauterization iron closed: then release the open cauterization for some time, and afterwards care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	¶ The method of cauterizing an abscess after its formation.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you are about to cut out an abscess, then use a hot cauterizing iron that is similar in size to the radius.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the hot cauterizing iron into the abscess: and use your last hand until the cauterizing iron reaches the opening of the wound, through which the blood flows: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If the abscesses are many, then cauterize each one according to what we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for it, with the ointment that it gives them, until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize it with a large cauterizing iron over the scarlet fever, it is the most final in the treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	¶ The method of cauterizing an anal fistula.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the weak patient does not obey the incision and operation that we have described in its place, and is afraid of it, perhaps it will heal with cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When a fistula occurs in someone and becomes old, runs pus from it, and the corrupted moistures:
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore, it is better that you should probe it with a fine probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the depth of its penetration when you probe it.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then he used a cauterization iron, which is similar to a radish.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then he inserted the burning iron into the fistula and the amount by which it entered the closing.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And he repeated the cauterization over that, until all the corrupted bodies burned, once, or twice, or three times, according to the quantity required by you.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard you from the burning of the nerve, if it is there, or a large wound; or if the fistula approaches to the body of the vesicae, or to the body of the intestine, then guard you from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do this unless the fistula is in a fleshy place: and think that it is not penetrable.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if a seal is on the place, and the matter is abscised from it for a long time: then you know that it has healed perfectly.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if the matter does not abscise from it: then you know that it is penetrable, or the deep part of it has a corrupted opening, or as if this were one of them: whose remembrance will not remain in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	¶ The method of cauterizing Rene's.
Caput XXXIX.	Head 39.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When a pain from cold or from the great dung occurs in Renus, and it weakens him because of that, then it is necessary to cauterize it over the alimentary canal over the same reins, with the cauterization over all the reins with the clauvise, whose remembrance precedes.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we will cauterize it a second time in the same alimentary canal.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Because three lines may come out.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore, they will be more at the end of the operation.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	The method of cauterization for a pimple (or pustule).
Caput XL.	Head XL.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the pimple due to cold and moisture, until it cannot hold the urine, then cauterize it on the lower side of the skin above the pimple, where the hair begins to grow thick and dense, and from both sides of the hand: let the length of the cauterization be according to the size of the pollex node: and cauterize it with the inferior cauterization on the back of the hand, or with two cauterizations if necessary there: and let it be according to what precedes the clapper.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	The method of cauterization for the maturity spot.
Caput XLI.	Head XLI.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture occur in the maturity spot, preventing conception, and the menstruations are corrupted, and the provocation of them is delayed, and a pain occurs in it at the time of their approach, then it is necessary for it to be cauterized with three cauterizations around the umbilicus, as I said in the cauterization of the pimple, and with a cauterization above the greater tubercle of the shoulder, or with two cauterizations: and let the clapper be the cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	The method of cauterization for the anchyloma in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Head XLII.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture of the mucous membrane reaches the anchyloma, and causes its exit from its place: and the sign of it is that the crus is prolonged above another, when they are compared to each other: and the place of dislocation is found to be watery in it.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary to cauterize the weak one with the same cauterization around the anchyloma: after which you see the signs when you encaustro in the circumference of the pus, as it revolves: and let it fall into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	The cauterizing instrument whose form precedes in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cauterizing instrument is not present for you, then cauterize it with three cauterizations, namely with a large olive oil cauterization: and let the depth of the cauterization be according to the thickness of the whole skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	§ Method of Cauterization in Sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When there is pain in the eye due to cold and moisture, and that is caused by frost: and the weak one is treated with that, as we said in division, and the cure is not given and it becomes antiquated: then it is necessary to dissolve the weak one from the thick humors with pills bitter and stinking, or with artificial pills and such like.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	The method of cauterization in this case is according to two methods: either with the cauterizing instrument when the drugs are being applied, or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	The cauterizing instrument with fire has many modes.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of which is, to cauterize over the cold eye with three triangular cauterizations, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And let them have a good or bad depth.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there should be space between the whole cauterizing instrument and the thickness of the finger, and the cauterizing instrument should be olive-oil.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	However, when the cauterizing instrument is made in the middle over the cold eye of the patient.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Why are there four cauterizations?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you want to cauterize with a circle, whose form precedes in the cauterization of the dislocation of the eye, one: so that the circle contains the whole eye.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the entire skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cauterization in Sciatica, when the pain is adhering to the anchae on the same side, and does not extend to the thigh and calf.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends to the thigh and calf, then cauterize it with two cauteries on the thigh, at the place where the weak one indicates, in which the pain is, and with your cauterization on the cauillam four fingers wide, on the slyest part perhaps: and let the cauterium be a hammer.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cauterization according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the weak one indicates that the pain extends to near the toes, then cauterize it wherever the weak one indicates with the point of the cauterization, three, or four, or more, if he desires that.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if the weak one indicates that the pain is under the knee and thigh, then cauterize it there with a single hammer-cauterization.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware in all your cauterizations that you do not always burn the nerve or the great artery with the cauterization, and do not harm the weak one with it, or cause a contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	Indeed I have seen one and another of those who cauterized above the cauillam, and inflated the thigh, until a tumor followed the foot, and was completely perforated, and completely corrupted, the whole foot: then resolution of the water occurred, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If the pain is in two parts at once, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And wise men have said in the cauterization of the anchae, whose is this mode of cauterization.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Create a similar one made of silver, whose diameter is the midpoint of the palm: and it should be at the orifice of its own according to the size of the tip of the finger, or slightly less: and within that silver, there should be another silver.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And there should be a space between all the silver according to the quantity of the pollical node: and the silver should be open from two sides: and the height of them should be like a node, or two nodes: and make for them appropriate manubria of silver in the silver.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then let it be heated in the fire until it turns red and emits sparks. Then it should be placed on a fine pitcher, slightly inclined, on the healthy side of the body.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore, let it be cauterized with three round cauteries in water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then release it after three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards, apply ointment with wax: and release the ulcer widely in many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says that in this case of cauterization by fire, we have not used it much due to the fear of its appearance, and therefore, because we have found only a few who expect on top of it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Nevertheless, it is from good cauterizations that he who suffers finds a place for it with it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	However, when the cauterization is with the medicines that are applied, as you will make two silver rings with holes, in which the door of its port comes down from air or iron, and the length of the side is equal to the height of the sides: and there should be two nodes in the height of them, or like themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And there should be a space between the two quantities of the size of the finger, and they should be open below and above: and it should be that they hold together according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then lay her on a sheet of linen, with the sick side down, lying on the sound side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand tightly over the sheet of linen.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of warm water, which is heated with fire as much as possible, and hold it for the time of the hour: and the sick one will endure the mordication of it and its own burning, for he found the mordication like fire, until the mordication ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then scrape your hand with the instrument and withdraw hot water from the wide part with sweet water, and then release it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place on top of that butter, until the blackness of the burning is removed: and release it for some days, and the pus will come out from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For this is the last in the dressing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for that with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the house or cruse, make a statue in it that contains water, according to what you made on the wide part equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the correction of physicians.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unburned lime, and grind both, and put one part of each in a new bowl, whose bottom has a small hole, according to the amount that enters the radius: and put another empty bowl under it: and dip both the alkali and lime in sweet water with your thumb: then close the bowl with your good compression: and release the bowl until sharp water enters the lower part of the empty bowl.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather all the water and pour it on the other lime: and hold it until it returns.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	It will be then that the true and strong bandage of acupuncture, which is administered in many medical operations and in the cauterization of other parts of the body.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it accomplishes the action of its own fire.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from the drugs themselves, which are used for cauterization, and as wide as tesis, and melted anacardium wax, and lime with soap, so that both are mixed together. ¶
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen indeed reportedly recounted, of a man from ancient times who was treated for pain in the ankle and sciatic nerve, and he praised the bandage as great. ¶
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said, because it is not needed for another treatment, and because it was cured with gut alone, unless he perhaps entered the bath that was led, and then left it already cured. ¶
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is said that it should be taken from the gut of a young woman: and if it is not found in a young woman, then it is dried, fresh: and it is applied much with some fat, and placed over the ankle, where the pain, or cramp, or in the thigh: and it is wrapped, and removed for three hours, or according to the amount that the weak person feels of the burning heat. ¶
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then insert it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When the body of him becomes rough, insert it into the seat. ¶
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain recedes, and it is cured. ¶
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you know that it is not necessary for anyone to use a cauterization with these drugs, unless after the evacuation of the body. ¶
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said that the feces of rabbits, when cauterized with it, nourishes the sciatic pain, and it is made as a bandage in this way. ¶
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	The wool is to be measured out, and it is to be soaked in old oil, and it is to be placed over the deep spot which is between the toe and the heel, and it is to be nearer the big toe than the little one.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the dry dung of a goat, and burn it in the fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place it over the wool, and let it be, until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat this.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	You shall not cease doing this, until the sense has passed through the middle of the bone to the hip, and the pain has ceased.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called the Vaccinium cauterization.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.
Caput XLIIII.	Head XLIII.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When a pain occurs in the back from various causes, or by chance, or by impact, or excessive evacuation, and such things, from cold and wet infusion: and cauterization indeed does not happen, unless in this very form, which is made from cold and wet infusion.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after the evacuation of the weak, with pills that are fetid and such like, it should be made over the back where the pain is, three lines according to the breadth of the treated part, after which signs are made with encaustic in every line five cauteries, or more according to the tolerance of the weak power of this part, and cauterization should be made with cauteriopuncti.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterization should be made with three or four cauteries, or more, with the cauterio closed medially, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.
Caput XLV.	Head XLV.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This type of illness often affects infants in childbirth.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its onset in boys is: that it occurs upon a stricture in the ankle during evacuation, and motion; and I found in the last vertebra of the back and the nodes of his, which has already begun to emerge above the others.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you see this, and you want to do this, then cauterize it with the cauterization that is a circle according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let the cauterization catch all parts of the vertebra equally: and if you want to cauterize in the circumference of the vertebra with the cauterization point two lines, or three: and they should be points close to the emerging one.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place until it heals with that which I said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And be careful not to give the cauterization in spasm of the muscle that is made in the gangrene.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	¶ About the method of cauterization in Podagra, and the pain of the joints.
Caput XLVI.	Head 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pain of the joints is caused by cold humors that are poured on any part of the body, then when the pain occurs in the feet, it is the custom of physicians to call this Podagra properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When Podagra is treated with cold causes of pain and the pains do not remain, then the cauterization removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is that the cauterization is done on him after evacuation in the circumference of the joints of the feet, with many cauterizations: and the cauterization should be olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is the form of it.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you need to make points on the face of the foot, then make with the cauterization points the points.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	When painful sensations rise up to the knees or other wounds, and this happens frequently, then cauterize the whole knee with three or four cauteries, or from all sides, with the same cauterization as Claudius.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If more is needed of this cauterization, then cauterize it again.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not dip your hand in the cauterization, rather it is about the thickness of the skin alone.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If painful sensations rise up to the knees and back, then administer what I have said from the cauterization chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If painful sensations are only in the hands, then make punctures around the focus, like the two lines that revolve.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If painful sensations remain in the fingers, then make punctures on all nodes with a single puncture, and on the thumb of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If painful sensations rise up to the elbows or hips after a day, then cauterize both from all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not discard the weak one from good management, from the reception of the physician.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regimen is made, and the phlegm is discarded, it will be healed with the help of God by this cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	§ On the method of cauterization in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groins, and the intestine descends, or the gut to the testicle, and this is nearest approaching: then it is necessary to let the weak one discard food on that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use gentle food, by which the feces may come out from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and make him hold his breath until he goes out, or shows the gut, or the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce again your fingers, and the signs with caustic under the rupture on the sides of the eyes, with a sign whose end is similar to half a circle in the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then apply the caustic, which is in this form, until it turns white and comes out as flakes.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine, or the colon to its connexion.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then place his hand over the place so that it does not escape from the intestine: and you have already opened between the weak thighs, and placed under it a pillow, and another on the crura of his other leg, and another on his chest which holds the hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the caustic over the sign with your hand holding the cauterium straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it, until when you reach the mouth: or go with another if you do not succeed with this one up to the mouth.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And observe wisely from the exit of the intestine in the hour of your cauterization, lest you burn it, and may appear by this on the weak or through malice great death.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not reach the mouth with the cauterium, your operation will not be successful.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cauterium for children be fine according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with the rest of the ointments until it heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let him be weak lying on his back for forty days, until the wound is scabbed over.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you place food on his length of time of curing according to the length of his wound healing so that his belly does not escape from the connexion and excretion.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when you want to rise after forty days, then administer the bandage made in a proper way, and hold it for forty days with others.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And it may be lessened by labor, and fullness of food and drink, and loud speaking.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when this regimen is used, it is cured wholly by the cure.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I say that the treatment of ruptures with incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however ruptures happen in the other belly, and they are beginning, and you do not wish them to be added, then cauterize the rupture with a round cauterization of the same quantity: and this which hardens from then on shall be as the third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then take care of it itself, according to what we have said: and it will not be added.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some have already said that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cauterization, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is set alight with the caustic, and a line is put across it which is along its width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line downwards.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the caustic closed.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the caustic is first easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	¶ About the method of cauterization in pain due to wound or percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Head 48.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens in some members by wound or percussion of pain: and he has endured the pain for a long time, and it does not consent to the cure with medicines: then it is necessary that it be cauterized with the point caustic.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And the caustic should be a cauterization for all members according to its size, and the parity of it, and its weakness, and its vigor, and its location of twisting, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If then it is cured by the first cauterization, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not, then proceed with the same cauterization.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For these pains are of habit, and they ought to be changed from the member towards that which is nearest to it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary to seize these pains with cauterization, until the weak one is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	¶ On the manner of cauterization in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	However, in leprosy sometimes the cauterization is made with the greatest cauterization.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of leprosy which is made for putrefaction of the phlegmatic and melancholic: since when you wish to cauterize it, consider it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If then leprosy is sloughing, and you have treated it with that which we said in the division, and it has not gone down, nor yet: and you fear for the weak one, that corruption may comprehend all the complexion of it: then cauterize it on the head with five burns: one in the middle of the head, and another under it at the end of the hair, and two under the two horns, and one under the nail of the little finger.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And then your hand with cauterization almost, until it makes an impression in the mouth of a small print, and the cortices are dislocated from it: that the breath of the gross vapors may escape from it, and cauterize also on the spleen, according as it precedes.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if leprosy has already spread over the weak one and appears clearly: then it is necessary to cauterize with those burns which we said in the head, and on the end of the nose, and two on the two maxillae, and two on the two spines of the neck, and six on the spine of the back, and one large on the hips and one above it, in the same hip: and two on the thighs, i.e. one on the whole thigh, and two on the knees, and two on the elbows, and two on the breast-bones of his own: and cauterize it on all the joints, from the joints of the fingers of his hands, and feet: and cauterize on all the heel of his feet, and the nails of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	Because of this, for the nerves that are above the last heel bone, so that they do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And when the caustic is applied to the os pectoralis, and another above the os stomachi, and another above the epar.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And you know that the more you add to the caustic, the more inflammation and the more consolidating it becomes.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you know that the weak do not find pain in the caustic as the healthy do, because their body is already stunned.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it should be that the caustics are according to their size and thickness, according to the parts and seams: according to what precedes from the types of tools.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the caustic from the flour of plants with honey, and the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	¶ On the method of cauterization in Stupor.
Caput L.	Head L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a certain member is stunned and is treated with medicines, oils, plasters, and does not heal, then cauterize the stunned member with caustics according to the size of the member or its thickness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And your caustic should be transverse in the thickness of the skin, almost.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with ointment until it is healed.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when a certain stupor occurs that happens to the hand and foot, and in the shoulders at the exit of the nerves that move that member: and the stupor is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	Indeed, do not assume it for that unless one is wise in the anatomy of the members, and the egress of the nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	¶ On the method of cauterization in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Head LIV.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When the ancient Albaras no longer contains anything of medical engineering: then cauterize over the deep cauterization as soon as possible, according to the degree of skin thickness, until the white removes and changes its color.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with flour of herbs, and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossum, and blood of the pigeon, and blood of the swallow: each part is one: mix all these together and they will stick to the cloth and remain in place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	¶ On the method of cauterization in cancer.
Caput LII.	Head LIV.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning and you want to hold it in place: then cauterize it with the cauterization circle around it, just as it rotates.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But wise men said that it should be cauterized with the last cauterization in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	But I do not see that: for I fear that it will ulcerate, and I have already seen that several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better to cauterize around it with a circle as we said, or with many cauterizations.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	¶ On the method of cauterization in adhesions.
Caput LIII.	Head LIV.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has adhesions and it is slow to mature, or because of the excessive making of it, or because of the weakness of the old, when there are few drops of blood, or because of time, and you want to hasten the maturation of the adhesions: then cauterize around it with many small cauterizations.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then release it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten with the maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If however you want to make a hole in it with the cauterization, then burn this one with the cauterization, whose form is this one.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it directly in the middle of the dressing, until it penetrates the skin: and let it be a cauterization from which a weak one follows, so that the course may be cleansed purely.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	§ Method of cauterization in corroding matter.
Caput LIIII.	Head LXXXIV. (This is likely a reference to the size or degree of the wound, not a patient's age or name.)
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	The corroding is only a decay in a walking member, and it corrodes itself, just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If then you see a corroding in the place where the cauterization can endure with fire, then much cauterization, small and large closures, according to which is suitable for that place where the decay is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until you completely remove the decay, and nothing remains of it deeply.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then release it for three days, and place over the cauterized spots powdered sulfur with oil, until all escharas are removed, and all decay.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then take care of it with the unguents that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If then you see that after three days healthy flesh is generated without decay, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cauterization over the remaining parts of the decaying ones.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And the corroding is sometimes treated with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it rises at the place of the cauterization.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Indeed, the cauterization with fire is more useful than the medicine: and I have already said that the cauterization of it with sharp medicine in division: take then it here when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	§ Method of cauterization in boils and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 57.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This affliction often occurs in the lower parts of the foot: it is a large, filtered thing that harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	Indeed, there is a caustic in those parts according to two ways: the caustic with fire, and the caustic with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	However, when it is with fire, it is like a feather made of flame: which is made of iron, according to the quantity that contains it, closed from all sides: and it has a fine edge.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the hot caustic on the closed part.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then roll the hand with the caustic around the closed part, until the caustic reaches the depth of the closed part: and let it remain for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply the plaster with ointment made of finely ground mustard, and salt: and let it be applied over the caustic at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with the generated skin ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they do not heal, and many of them occur on the surface of the body, especially on the hands and feet: then apply the caustic with hot water to them: and it is like taking a canula from air, or iron, or from a feather: and place it over the closed part, or an althelul.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then draw out a small amount of hot water from the canula: hold your hand, and roll it with the compression of your hand, so that the edge of the canula is imprinted on the depth of the closed part, and it finds warm water to the root, to the depth: and it will wait weakly for a short time after the application of hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let it go, for it will be uprooted along with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do it one after another until all of them are removed from the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of them after they have been uprooted, with the ointment that generates flesh from the wound.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	¶ Method of Cauterization in Tremors.
Caput LVI.	Head 60.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When a tremor occurs in someone due to cold in the nerve, or due to a fever of the fourth kind, or otherwise: then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauterizations, or five over the back of the spine, and over all the back, and in the chest of that person, and over the stomach of that person.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For the tremor ceases with the olive oil cauterization, and hastens the health of the illness of cold.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	¶ Method of Cauterization for Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Head 57.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When the foetid Albathir spots that are formed from the corrupt materials of the body are expelled from the body.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, it is necessary to first cauterize them when they appear, with the olive oil cauterization over all the head spots, with a fine myrtle stick, whose ends are burned with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or if the long root of the Aristolochia is used.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or if the cauterization with the lens is used.
