Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the hour of the piercing of the appointed one, which is ripe according to the complement: and it is near sedation of the pain, recession of the fever, and diminution of the rubedness, and pulsation of the head apostema, and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same piercing in the lower part of the appointed one, and more prominent eminence: and the piercing should be wanding in the length of the body, if the appointed ones are in parts of hands and feet, and of fingers, and of strings, and of strings, and of nerves, and of arteries, and at the last in all equal places where there is no reflexion.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those that reflect, wand with the piercing according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When the appointed one is in flesh: then it is better that you let pass the piercing of it, until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said according to the complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Since you pierce it before that, the course will be prolonged for a long time from it, and there will be many fouls and bitterness, and perhaps its lips will become hardened, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some piercings are made according to the body's breadth at the time of need: or according to that which the member requires.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	It is necessary to make the piercings in the pubic region with a small perforation, and in the larger ones with a large perforation: or make many sections according to the size of the piercing.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And they are from the piercings where it is necessary to cut the skin: and it is applied when the skin is already like a cloth, and it is applied at the end when it is already dead: just as that which happens in many cases, such as the nipples, and the bubons.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from them there are those that are cut with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from them there is one, according to which it is applied like the figure of the myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Just as the pubic piercings.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And from them there are those in which a round section and a lunar section are applied: and similar ones are made from these sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	However, if it does not have a head, like the surface piercings, it is necessary to pierce it with a superficial perforation, or only flat.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary when the piercing is large, and it has already collected a lot of healthy tissue, and it pierces it, so that not too much pus is taken out at once: in fact, take out that part of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then fill the piercing up to another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then take out some pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Perform this frequently according to the gradation, until it goes out: especially if the person is weak in bodily strength, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man with decrepit bones: for the animal spirit, being resolved from one animal to another on going out through the sore, may perhaps cause the death of the weak one, and you may not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, this chapter requires great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And then, after your perforation, which you made with the apostemata for this purpose, it is necessary to cleanse the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If then the wound is small from the apostemata, or if it is a flat section, then apply a linen bandage, or an old hat.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the wound is large, and there are many perforations, then it is necessary to insert a bandage into all the fissures until they become moist.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in the wound you have cut away a part of the skin, or have cauterized it around: then it is necessary to fill it with an old hat, or as when the cloth is tied, or when the hair of linen is combed without moisture: and tie it up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take it out, and care for it with the ointment, until it is cured.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if blood flows in your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after the cloth has absorbed it: and place it over the place where the blood flow is great.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the flow of blood persists, then it is necessary to give a regimen and treatment, and plasters, which I have mentioned in many places of this our books, and by division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the winter season, and the wound is of many nerves: then it is necessary to apply plasters with wine, and hot oil: and place them over the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	If it is summer and the area is fleshy: then you should put poultices made with water and oil, or wine and oil, and all of this should be cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	When the third day comes, as we have said, then you should dissolve the style, cleanse it, and administer to its treatment what is suitable for it until it recovers.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from the knowledge of the surgery of the style generally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the second division, as I have said about every style, how it is to be used for its treatment, specifically in this case.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	¶ About the section of the style that happens on the scalp.
Caput XLI.	Head 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Styles that happen on the scalp are small and come from the species of Nodulus, which are found in the clothes made of these shells, which are like the husks of grapes.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their species is many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are fat ones: and among them are those that contain like moisture as of the limbs: and among them are those that contain like the moisture of flints and pellitory: and such as these, and among them are those that are hard like stones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the whole section, and there is no fear of its extraction, while it does not cause any contrariety in the artery at its own section.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their section is as you will find it with the instrument which comes after this, called the Intromissive, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains moisture, then you should dry it in the section according to the length of the surface section, in this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the section from line b to line g. And when the moisture is evacuated, then you scrape off the chalk which contains that moisture, and do not let anything pass through it.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	Many times it returns, if something remains from it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the stomach in Egyptian ointment, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the belly with it, and let it go until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will itself corrode that remains from the box.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then go over the stomach with Egyptian ointment a second and third time, and if you need it, until you trust that nothing will remain from the box, then care for the belly with the ointment until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the aposteme contains a red node, then cut it according to this form, with a cross-shaped section: and pull out the hairs between the two sections of the section, and rub it all over: and trust in your virtue in extracting the tunic that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If the artery causes you contrariness, then do what I will tell you after.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly, do in the aposteme if it is of stone, according to the section and care that I mentioned earlier.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section over the stone aposteme is easier: because it is few in blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some of these aposteme in the head of certain men, where there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I followed over the aposteme in the head of a young woman, and found an aposteme like a hard, solid, rough, white stone, which could not be broken: and if it is pricked with anything while being pulled out, it wounds itself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In others however, accidents in the head of the aposteme, except for these aposteme that happen in the heads of children, and among the roots of gold, the section of all of them is a superficial section.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Either cut off their nails from below, always from the lower part of their nails, so that the course of the sanies might flow downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then attend to it with caution, as it may harm them in their treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	§ Section on the Stripped Throat in the Neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur in the neck, under the armpits, and in the groin, and sometimes in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those that occur above them in the neck are few, and many; they are caused by the cold: and every Strophula of them is within the patient's own clothing, just as is the case with nodes and abscesses of the head, as we have said.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the species of these abscesses are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	For they are made up of stone: and some of them are dry: and some of them are malignant, and do not obey treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that which appears to be a good abscess in the skin, of which the color of the skin is manifestly close to it, and moves over all parts, and is not annexed to the neck muscles, nor to the jaw, nor to the artery, nor is deep: it is necessary to cut it out superficially from the upper part down to the lower part of the body, along line b. to line g., and scrape it off from all parts: and extend two lips of the skin with the beard, or with many beards, if you desire that, as we said in the abscesses of the head, and draw it out a little at a time.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is over the cauterant, so that it does not come into contact with the mind, or the nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And it should be rough but not sharp: so that it does not add to your hand when you make the incision, or disturb the weak, and you cut where you do not need to.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If you happen to injure a vein, an artery, or prevent yourself from performing the operation, then place the cut end of a piece of reed in the vulna, or some children who cut blood vessels, and tie the vulna, and let it go until the sharpness of the splinters has subsided and the vulna has become soft, or begins to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is now flowing, then return to your operation, until you have completed it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then, with your finger, inquire if anything remains of the Strophuli among the others: then cut those, and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If the wen in the root of the Strophula is large, then it is necessary not to cut that Strophula from its root: rather, it is necessary to bind it with a strong thread doubled, and let it go until it falls on its own without causing any harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the old vulna with the Egyptian ointment that you have already submerged.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the entire Strophula is cut, then it is necessary to gather the two lips of the wound together, and stitch them immediately, after which you should see that there is no surplus.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If you see that there is surplus due to the size of the Strophula, then it is necessary to consider cutting its root and taking it out, and apply the stitch I mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And if it contains humidity from the Strophula, make a superficial puncture in it: so that you can see the place of its maturity for you: and place the puncture below the body as I said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply the hair after the puncture with ointment, and similar to it, so that what remains of corruption may rot until you see the vulna already clean: then take care of it with the ointment generated by the flesh, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Sectioning the Epiglottis near the stoma in the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients performed this sectioning on the epiglottis, and I have not found anyone in our land who has done this. This is a record of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	However, in those who have synchondrosis, it is necessary to avoid sectioning the epiglottis: because if there is no inflammation through this, it is because all the veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	However, in those who have hot synchondrosis in the mouth, or throat, or both, when there is no inflammation in the arytenoid cartilages, it is necessary to use sectioning of the epiglottis to avoid destruction that comes from prefecture.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we want to do this, it is necessary to make a small incision in the epiglottis under three circles of the epiglottis, or four, using a circular motion in the area that is between the two circles, not in the cartilage: and this is a suitable place for sectioning, because it is fatty and the blood vessels are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, then it is necessary to extend the skin of the throat with a retractor.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he finds the skin, until he becomes wet with the air: he avoids the blood vessels, if he sees anything in them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he sews the sifac that we have described: and this signifies above the cut in the bronchus, when it comes out of it with that which is broken off, and by abscission of the tongue.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And release the groin at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour comes that you fear prefecture, gather together the two lips of the skin wound, and take it alone without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that bring forth the flesh until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis said.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this discourse, which we have related, is not an explanation, unless they understand that some of these apostemata have already weakened the infirm gullet: and the weak one has risen above death, and desires to be separated from the pain of its death: they apply to cut the epiglottis, so that the weak one may breathe above the place of the wound with a certain breathing, and be saved from death: and for this reason they were commanded to leave the open wound unstitched, until the malice of the disease has consumed it, and the malice of the disease is three days old, and almost itself: then, therefore, they were commanded to close the open wound and care for it, until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw through me, that one maid received a sword and sent it with her throat, and it fell with her into the part of the lung's canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to care for it, and I found it hissing, as is the hiss of the dead.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	Therefore, I removed the wound from the gut, and found blood that had issued from the small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore, I was confident that it had not closed the wound, nor cured it: and the air was escaping from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Therefore, I quickly applied to it and cared for it, until it is healed: and nothing happens to the maid, unless there is a rushing in the throat: and she returned after days to a better disposition of herself.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore, I say that there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	¶ About the Section of Gut Hernia.
Caput XLIIII.	Head XLIII.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This Hernia of the Neck is a large ailment, according to the color of the body: and it is very common in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it occurs in two ways: either it is natural, or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly not in the natural case.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental one is according to two modes: one of which is similar to small pendulous tumors.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other mode is similar to the hernia that occurs from the nodulation of the artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear itself, and it is not proper to make an assumption about it with iron, unless it is in the small one: and you examine it yourself, and investigate it when you insert.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then you find it similar to the small pendulous tumor, and it is not suspended with any strings: then dry it, as is done with the nodules: and remove it along with whatever is contained in the purse, if it is in the purse: and if not, then examine the whole of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with what is necessary for healing until it is cured.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	§ On the Section of the Species of Nodules.
Caput XLV.	Head XLV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many species of nodules, and I have already mentioned all the species of these in division: and it is necessary to point out the difference between the nodule and the exit: as there is a doubt about it.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say that when the exit is heat, and fever, and severe pains, until the ebullition of the superfluous boiling is extinguished, and the putridity is completed: then the fever and heat are quiet.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But when the nodule is not heat, nor fever, nor pain, and it contains them in the purse of sifachin which is their own sack, and it is according to the color of the body: and it is like the chestnut, and it is like the hatchet, and it is greater and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	They are of two kinds: either they are fatty, or they retain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colors of moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when dealing with swelling for treatment of Nodi, you should first try it out and then look into the instrument called Intromissive, according to its form in the chapter that follows this one.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of inspection is as follows for all Nodi: take this instrument and insert it into a moister place that you find in the apostemate: and then rotate your fingers with it gradually, until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then take the last hand of yours according to the measure of the apostemate's size.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then take out the Intromissive and look at what goes into the wound.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If it runs out with moisture of any color, then cut it off at the surface section, according to what I said in the others apostemates.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if it does not run out with moisture in the wound of the Intromissive, then you know that it is fatty. Then cut off the section with a cross-shaped form, according to the form I showed you: and suspend it with thongs, and exfoliate the skin from all parts with ease: and guard the kistin if you can, so as to take out the healthy one with the Nodi.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the kistin is broken at the operation and it is not possible to take out the healthy one, often this happens, then take it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if a little remains of it, or much, the Nodi return according to the most.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it does not heal you, and there remains a little of it: then fill the wound at the completion of your operation with some sharp-edged children's thorns, and tie them up, and put above it the hot apostemate, and care for it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If then the knot is large, then its two lips, and care for it with it that it perishes.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If then the contrary evil is a small one, or not small: then at once, and fill the place with a sharp point, and release it tightly for two days, or three, until the wound putrefies, and rests in the ebb of the blood: then return to incise the remainder of that knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	¶ About foreign instruments for cutting and perforating.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Of these there are three kinds: and they are of three species.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For these are large, and one is medium, and one is small.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be made of steel quadrants, with sharp ends, so that they may quickly enter the apostemates.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of instruments for exploration and no, that is, for perforating: and one of them is called borer, that is, a piercer: and they are of three species.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For these are large, and one is medium, and one is small.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They come together, so that they may explore through them the apostemates, and exits, and fistulas, and bones from which it is between them.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, thin, soft, like a large needle, which sit on carpets, either of citrine, or of air, or of iron, or of silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the better of these are those which are made of citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And they are also instruments of lead black, which come together so that they may explore the fistulas, whose reflectivity is such that they reflect with the lenity of their own reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are indeed three kinds again.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For they are either long, or medium, or short, according to the size of the fistula and its stricture.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of the ninth, and they are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For there are among them simple ones, that is, those of a single stricture: and they are three kinds as you see, the Great, the Medium, and the Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And there are among them the blind of the ninth: and they are three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And there are among them the ones with two strictures: and they are three kinds: and there are also those with three strictures: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of the scalpel blades, by which the roots of the thorns, and the spines are cut off and stripped: and they are three kinds: for there are among them a great, a medium, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities by which the section is made are sharp, while their other extremities are not sharp: and they are not placed thus, except when with them there is a stimulus for the stripping of the thorns in fear of the incision, or of the nerve: and so that it may heal by these, and find tranquility rather than what it finds at the stripping of the spines.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are the Mada, and they are of three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of metal, and they are like the Rhodium, when alcohol is made: and at the wide end there is a hidden point of Spatumilis: and it runs to the inside and the outside, whenever you wish, just as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the Spatumilis which is hidden between the fingers at the time of the spine stripping: and they do not perceive it with the weak: and they are three kinds, a great, a medium, and a small one.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The three kinds of winds that are cut off with blood flow are: the large, medium, and small ones.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	May they be made from air or saffron, round, and of about the same length as you see, and they should be fine.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of winds be at your disposal: the large and small ones, so that you can cut off blood flow with them in case of need, and then when there is no medicine present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, you will not use them in all parts of the body for blood cutting, and you will only use them in places where there is flesh: such as the thighs, hips, shoulders, breasts, mammary glands, and vaginas, and urethras, and groins, and similar parts, from the thighs of flesh, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they become small instruments of the same kind as the fistulas of the flesh, according to their shape: which cut off blood when it flows from the site of phlebotomy, or at the incision of the vein, or artery: and sometimes they become round according to this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	¶ About the care of human breasts that resemble those of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of some men swell up when they reach the complement of sleep (that is, when they start to pollute in sleep) until they are like the breasts of women: and they remain infected with the poison.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore, if he abhors this, it is necessary to apply the moon's section to the breasts according to this shape from the line b to the line g, and then to rub off the grease entirely.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards, fill the wound with medicated gut.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather the two lips of the wound with the suture, and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If the nipple leans towards the lower parts and becomes soft due to its size, like in women: then it should be divided into two equal parts on the upper sides, each containing a lunar figure, of which one is contained within the other at the edges of both, until the larger line encompasses the smaller, according to this form from line b to line g. Then scrape off the skin that lies between the two lips and remove the moisture, and apply what I have mentioned about the suture and buttons, which is necessary for the cure, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If the incision does not cover the part that needs to be cut because of weakness or due to the flow of blood: then it should be filled with a wound ointment under the scalp, and released until the remaining part is cut by dryness.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	¶ Regarding the puncture of the stitch, which happens under the Titillus.
Caput XLVIII.	Head 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These stitches that happen under the Titillus are hard species of Strophulus, which contain buttons, and some of them have moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore, those that have moisture among them should be cleaned with the lunar figure according to this form, from line b to line g, when the entire part that is in the puncture from the wound has been discharged, then fill it with the old ointment under the scalp, and release it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the dressing is removed and the wound is cared for with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the nature of the Strophula thorn, then cut down upon it as we have said in the section on Strophulas, equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	However, if the finger is extended in this way to let out the pus, then apply cauterization in that place as we have said in that which has been said about that which was previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	¶ Regarding the section of the abscess that occurs due to the artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Head 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is torn and the skin that is above it consolidates, a great abscess often occurs thereafter: and so does the vein also, as does the inflammation in that abscess.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the abscess and inflammation are due to the artery and vein are: for when the abscess is due to the artery, it is long, gathered in the deep part of the body; and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a cracking in it.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to the vein is round in the manifest part of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section above this abscess is an error, and particularly that which is under the scales, and in the groins, and in the neck, and in many parts of the body: and it is a great pain.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, it should be neglected with iron, and that even if it is in the extremities or at the head, it should be neglected.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, above that which is from the inflammation of the artery's opening, find in the skin section in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with the rings, then the artery: and free it from the clothes, until it is exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert the knife under it, and make it penetrate to the other side, and tie the artery with double thread in two places, according to what I taught you in the extraction of two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then press the place which is between the two ligatures with sand, until all the blood that is in it comes out, and dissolves the aposteme.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply the dressing which generates pus, until the ligatures fall: then cure it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is an aposteme due to the section of the vein, then it is necessary for you to hold your hand with which you can possibly take out the aposteme with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the knife under the place where you held with your hand, and make it penetrate: and there should be a double thread in it, until it is taken out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the aposteme with the same good ligature: according to what I told you in the good gauze ligature, with two parts from two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you fear that the thread will be taken out, then insert the knife another one with another thread completely at the incision of the needle: press, and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the aposteme in the middle of it, until when it comes out that is in it: then cut the excess skin, and let what is tied out from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on top of it a little ointment which you dipped in the wine.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply the dressing which is made with laver and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.
Caput L.	Caput L. (This is the Latin term for "Chapter L".)
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportit ut inuadatur cum ferro.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Fortasse enim accidet contractio.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Et si ergo est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uolnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanatur.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.
Caput LI.	Caput LI. (This is the Latin term for "Chapter LI".)
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root is fine and delicate, and their head is coarse and their lips are crossed.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it is small from them, and it is from them that the beauty is exaggerated.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	Indeed, I have already seen a man, and within his belly were two thyme leaves, which were more than similar foods: there was no difference between them, white and small roots, and their lips moved, and they were moist throughout.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore I touched it and found in the weight of one almost 18 and 8 ounces and in the other almost 6 ounces. The operation in their incision is, as you see now, if the humid is weak, and the color of the thyme leaves is white, moist, and delicate root: then touch it with a slightly damp sponge side, and let your cauteries be present in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For much blood is expelled at the cutting of this section: therefore if you do not bleed, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a weak and timid man after the cutting with iron, then take a thread from the plumb made in accordance with what I have said, and string it with it, which is called athelul: whose mode I have mentioned, and release it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the plumbing of the plumb.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	You do not stop stringing the plumb until it is no longer pressed into the thyme leaves, until it is cut off, and falls without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the thyme leaves are coarse and rooted, then there is some fear and weakness in the cutting of this section: especially in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless, it may be possible to touch the middle of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of it itself, until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you presume to touch the spot that is of a wheat color, few senses, unpleasant appearance: for it is in reality a cancerous growth, and I am speaking after reflection on Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	¶ On the care of the prominence of the umbilicus.
Caput LII.	Head LXXII.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	It is caused by many causes in the umbilicus.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures of the umbilicus that are above the ventrum, and it exits through the althub, or the intestine, according to which happens in the others ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows out of the vein, or from the artery, according to which was first mentioned.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the congestion of the ventrum in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If however it is due to the fissure of the umbilicus and the exit of thirbi, then the color is similar to that of the body's color, and it is soft, without pain, and appears with various sites.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the exit of the intestine, then the site of it is with that which we have mentioned, with a more pronounced diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it is hidden: then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound at that time: and it is greatly magnified among the introduction of the bath and the labor of the weary.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If however it is due to moisture, it is soft, and it is not hidden when you press it with your hand, nor is it contracted, nor is it added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	What if it is due to blood, then with these signs appears the apostema to blackness from the clitoris.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If however it is due to the flesh that is born, then it is apostema gray, heavy, hard, and appears according to the quantity of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If indeed it is due to its wetness, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in that case is, as you consider, if the prominence of the umbilicus is due to blood in the Artery, or Vein, or wetness: then it is necessary for you to prevent its treatment.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and weakness, as I told you in the chapter where I said that abscesses are due to the Artery and Vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominence of the umbilicus is due to the intestine or gut: then it is necessary for you to precede the weak one, until he holds his thirst and stands firm extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with the encaustic around the whole umbilicus.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then order him to rise up between your hands on his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround it with a mixture of soap on the place where you marked with the encaustic.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the abscess to the upper part, with a large uncino.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie it around the strong part with thread, or with a cord of silk, and make the knot firm: and let the node of the ligature be in the flesh.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the abscess extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If then you find it already taken out from the ligament: then take out the node by the flesh, and insert your finger indicated, and press the intestine into the interior of the belly: and if you find the gut: then take it with a uncino and cut off its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If however the opposite is to you the Artery or Vein: then surround it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and insert two strong threads into them: and insert two needles in the circumference which you made around the abscess in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tie the aposteme in four places on the needle: and if you will, take away the needle, and leave the place, until the stretched flesh putrefies: and it will fall of its own accord: or it may fall when it is made thin and putrid.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with the ointment until it is cured.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the protuberance of the umbilicus is from the fatty flesh in it, or from moisture: then it is necessary to cut the aposteme as I have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out the blood, or the moisture that I find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of it with the ointment until the place is healed.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	¶ Regarding the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 35.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	I have already spoken of the division of the species of cancer, and how it is useful for its treatment with remedies: and it must be taken into account when treating it with iron so that it does not ulcerate: and I have said that cancer generated in the womb, and the caution against its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that when cancer is in a place where its removal is possible, just as the cancer which is in the breasts, or in the thigh, and such like, from the situated members to extract the whole of it: especially when it is beginning male.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	But when it becomes old and large, it does not need to be near it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I myself could not cure anyone from it: nor did I see anyone before me who had been cured of it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it when it is situated as I have said, is as I have already mentioned, and dissolves the weakness from black vomit repeatedly.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find a phlebitis with the apparent fullness:
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then make the patient ready for the preparation, in which the operation will take place.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then excise the warts that are close to him.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterwards, remove the entire growth from all sides according to the incision, until nothing remains of its roots: and let blood flow freely, and do not cut it off rashly, but clearly mark the limits, and wipe away the bloody fluid with your own hand, or with whatever is available near the instrument.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	However, if the flow of thick blood from the incision of the artery or vein occurs against your will, then cauterize the wound until the blood is exhausted.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	¶ Regarding the treatment of hydrops.
Caput LIIII.	Head 135.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already described the division of species hydrops, and how the aggregation of water occurs, as well as the signs of all kinds and the treatment of it with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And those that are treated with iron are not except for the single species of aculeatus, and do not approach with iron the species of timpanite, nor the nearly mortal species of hyposarcia, because it is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this species of hydrops timpanite with medicines and your treatment did not include it, then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the patient has already been weakened by the illness, or if there is another infirmity with it, such as tussis or watery discharge, and similar to these: then be careful not to treat it with iron, because that is the fear.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	However, if you see an infirmity of excessive vigor, there is not only illness with it apart from hydrops, and it is not a child nor an old man: then the mode of the operation in him is, that you remove the infirm one standing between your hands, and the minister after it presses his breath on its inferior part of the beard.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then receive a sponge-like spongy one, according to this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Let it have two sharp parts, long, and sharp at both ends, like a sponge-like one.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	However, there should be a slight thinness in it, so that you do not pierce through it with the operation up to the intestine, and hurt it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the generation of Hydriosis is from the intestines, then it is necessary to extend it with the cut at the umbilicus, in a quantity of three fingers, downwards in direct ratio above the chest.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If indeed, the generation of Hydriosis is due to the suffering of the breast: then your cut should be left at the umbilicus, in three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the generation of this is due to the spleen: then the cut should be made on the right side: and it is not necessary that the cut should also be on the right side over which you want to place the weak one, so that superfluities do not run to that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then perforate with the tool the entire cut.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert into that cut, and scrape with your hand the Spatumili between the cut and the skin, and scrape it as if you were scraping off the nail: and the quantity to be scraped should be equal to the quantity of the nail, or about this.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then scrape until the Spatumili reaches the empty place: and it is the place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then extract it, and insert into the hole of the instrument, which is this form.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is like a cannula: made of silver, or of air, or of aurichalco, and of linen, tersum: which on the bottom side has a small hole, and on its sides have three holes, two from one part, and one from another part: and the end of it is cut, according to the mode of the knife, as you see: in the top end there is an armillary sphere.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	When the instrument is wet with water, then it immediately sinks into the water, therefore it absorbs half an hour's quantity of water.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	Because if you absorb more water than is proper, in an hour it may happen that the weak one dies by a resolution of its animal spirit: or it happens to him that he has a syncope which approaches to death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	Indeed, the absorption of water is according to the vitality of the animal, and according to what you understand, the weakness of its pulse and its goodness.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then take out the instrument, and keep the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	That is, because it holds immediately due to the skin which holds the opening that is on the face: of which I will tell you, in order to perforate it according to that mode.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the instrument on the other day, if you see the weak one enduring that: and also take out a smaller quantity of water.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this several days without fear, and guard yourself from error: until there remains but a little water.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	But if you fear for the weak one and release much water from it: then take care of it with hot sand, and much sweat in the bath and sun, and expect over the time: and take care of it with the medicines which have been extinguished, until it is healed: and cauterize over the stomach, and the spleen, and the liver, after the water has been extracted: according to what I will tell you which precedes.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	¶ Regarding the care of children who are born in places where their urinary openings have not been made:
Caput LV.	Head 50.
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When any child leaves its mother's womb, and the head of the child is not perforated, or the opening is narrowed, or it is not in its proper place:
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	It is therefore necessary to provide assistance immediately after the hole is made, with a solution of salt and water, according to this form.
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then place a fine wire in the hole from lead, and tie it: and keep it for three days, or four.
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When you wish to urinate, remove it, and mix.
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then reduce it again.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	And if you do not place the lead, it is possible that the urine which comes to the place will not allow it to be closed.
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	However, the one whose hole is narrow, is treated with lead, as I said, for many days, until it is enlarged.
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	However, those in which the hole is not in its place, are harmed.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	What is, that the hole is made at the end of the female child's head: therefore it cannot mix with the front, until she lifts herself by her own hand to the upper part.
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	Nor is it for her generation, therefore, because the seed cannot come to the womb according to the rightness: and it is a painful disease.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	And the method of the operation in that is, that it is laid weak on its back.
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then extend the head of that female child with your left hand, and cut the head of the female child's head from its place, with a sharp edge, or with sharp salt: as is the cut of a razor, or as you do with rods something similar to the middle of the head of a female child: and let the hole fall in the middle according to what is necessary.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	And be careful for you at your operation with the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For it often happens that.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Therefore place it with it that cuts the blood, and take care of the wound, until it is healed.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	Of Albugines that happen in the prepuce and head of the penis, blackness, corruption, nigrescence, and adhesion.
Caput LVI.	Head LVI.
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	These Albugines often happen in the female genitalia, and it is a prominent unsightly flesh.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	And from this another is malicious, and another not malicious.
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	Therefore, non-malicious it is necessary to hang with a fine uncinate, and cut it off, until it is washed in its entirety.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then place above it a submerged gut in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	Then care for it afterwards with the ointment dysentery, until it is healed.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	And if the Albugine is malicious, of a unpleasant color, then it is necessary to apply cauterization to it after its incision and its section.
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	And if the Albugine is in the prepuce of a virgin, not circumcised, and it is a part of the Albugine between the prepuce and its own outside: then it is necessary to remove the Albugine that is inside first, until it is solid, then care for it externally, because when you care for it at the same time, the prepuce does not become erect.
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And they also happen in the testicles, and in the prepuce blackness and corruption.
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	Therefore, it is necessary to cauterize the whole that is already blackened and that you want to corrode, or already corrupted.
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then a line over it afterwards with the ointment that has already been ground with flour of barley and the wool of the goat.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
