Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then the midwife should sit on the left side, and administer the instrument with which the matrix opening is opened.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose form comes to them that are behind.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary when you are to administer this instrument that you make it like the deep groove of a woman's radio: so that what comes in through the instrument is not more than the depth of the groove, and does not hurt the weak one.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	However, if the instrument is greater than the depth, then it is necessary to put pills on the top of the deep groove: so that the introduction of the instrument's whole is prevented into the deep groove: and it is necessary that the pill run in the instrument from the upper side: and that it holds the instrument, and that it rolls the pill until the deep groove is opened.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When the Exitus appears, and is touched with the hand, and it is soft and smooth: then it is necessary that it be left in its own head with a wide slice of soap.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When the sanies are discharged, then it is necessary that you put in the vulva of a linen submerged in rose oil: or in virgin oil, in which there is some stipticity: and put the linen in, and take out the section from the deep groove.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And put outside on the mattress, and on the clean wool that is submerged in water, in which the bullfats are of the lower class.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then it is dressed after two days with the ointment that is suitable for this, until it is healed.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And sometimes the mattress and vulva are washed so that they are cleansed with water and honey: then with water in which the root of the lily or long Aristolochia: then return to the ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	That if the vulva is hidden inside the mattress, then it is necessary that you prevent the care of its iron with care, even the care itself with what I said in division.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	Doctrines of Midwifery, how they treat fetuses from birth, according to a non-natural figure.
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter 78.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the midwife to recognize the first figure of the natural childbirth.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	When you see a woman being compressed towards the lower parts and she desires to smell the air above her, and she blows over that which is above her, which is on the same level as the birth, and she hurries the exit of the embryo: then you know that this childbirth is according to a natural figure, and its exit is from the head of it, and afterwards with it. Or, if suspended, or hanging from the umbilicus.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When you see these signs, then it is necessary to compress its belly, so that the embryo may come out quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it comes down to its head, the rest comes with it, and it is washed clean of these superfluities by good cleansing.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	But if it is beyond this childbirth, it is unnatural and shameful.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For sometimes the embryo comes out of its feet, and it comes out of the body of it before the head of it, and the feet and hands of it, and one foot: or the head of it and the hand of it: or the forehead of it and the hand of it: or it comes out by the belly: and perhaps it turns over on its chest, and such like from unnatural figures.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	Therefore it is necessary for the midwife to be wise and subtle in all these things, and to guard against error and deception. And I am showing you all the figures from them, and what intelligence is in them, and what it means by that, and how it stands over it.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the embryo comes out of its head by its natural exit, and it stands over the woman, and it is difficult for it to have a child, and you see its virtue already weakened: then let it sit on its seat, or women hold it: and if it is weak with foenugraeco decocted, and with oils.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the midwife inserts her hand into the patient's vagina, finds the presenting part with it, and seizes it with her thumb, until the fluid that is in it has dried up due to dryness: and presses on the woman's abdomen until the fetus descends.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If the fetus does not descend, then it is necessary that the woman be anointed with Greek mucilage with olive oil.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then press on him to swallow it: and make it stupefy him with condiments, and hold his mouth and nostrils for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	For the fetus will soon pass.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If both hands of the fetus come out first, then it is necessary to gently reduce them with some difficulty.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If she does not obey during the introduction, then place the woman on a bed, and raise her feet: then press the bed on the ground: and hold her so that she does not fall during the shock.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If the hands do not come out, and the fetus dies: then cut off the hands, and extract the remaining fetus: and tie the hand of the fetus with a cloth, and take it out with equality: for it will also come out.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The exit of the embryo from its foot.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus comes out of its feet, then it is necessary to push them up: then turn the fetus slightly: and finally hold it.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then take one of its feet, and extend it slightly.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they come out until the thighs, then press on him to swallow it, and make it stupefy him with condiments: for he will come out if God wills.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if he does not come out with him as we have told you, then gently reduce the fetus slightly until you place it according to the natural figure.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	He will then go out easily.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If anything is forbidden to go with him, take some highly alkali ointment, and then some bitter oil, and some dissolved gum: mix them all in the mortar by good percussion, and then apply a line of it to the woman's vulva, and below her ventricle.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make her sit in warm water until she gets drowsy.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When you see that the lower parts of her are already heated, then apply some myrrh to it, and put it on.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When she has held the ointment for an hour, then make her sit on a seat.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make her snort: and draw up her nose and mouth, and press on the lower part of her ventricle by easy pressure.
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the fire will go out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	Exit of the fetus on the thighs and hands.
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When she goes out according to this form, then let her insert her hand slowly into it.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman will lie down on her neck, and her feet should hang down, and she should lie down on the bed, and fold her hands.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then press on her ventricle by easy pressure.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then take out what is under her feet from the clot, until it is ready in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not go out, then take her feet and move them with a strong movement.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then press on what is above the drowsiness by easy pressure, until the fetus goes up to the upper part.
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then let her insert her hand slowly, and press on the fetus, and tell the woman to hold it until the fetus goes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The exit of the fetus hanging freely from the hands.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	It is ingeniously reduced in its hand.
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	However, if it cannot be reduced, then make the woman walk, and let her walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If however she cannot walk, then make her lie down on the bed: and strike her thighs with a violent blow.
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then apply the liniment you have prepared from mucilages that you have.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If however she accepts it, then make her sit on the seat.
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then carefully reduce her hand, and evenly grasp the fetus according to its natural figure, and make her compress herself, and tell her to hold tight until she exits.
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The exit of the fetus over its own neck, with its hands expanded, and its face towards the back of her mother's.
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	It is necessary that the midwife hold onto the hand of the fetus, then gently roll it, and ease it with facility.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When it is eased, then place on top of its navel that we have mentioned from oil and mucilages.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then tell her to move gently.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done that, then make her sit on the seat, and tell her to lean towards the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then tell her to compress: and make her hold tight with a pinch.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The exit of the fetus prepared on the side.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it descends to the mother's opening according to this method with the second, then cut the second with your nail, until it is dry from moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If however it is hung over the face of the fetus and its neck, then cut it from the navel: so that it may not be held, and it may die.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus inside, until you place it according to what is appropriate: and tell the woman to clasp herself several times: for he himself will go out by the left side.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	Exit of twins or of many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are born frequently: and sometimes three, and four.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	However, that is extraordinary and rarely happens.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five is indeed beyond nature and do not live together: and they contain them, however many there may be, in one first: and they are separated by the finger, distinguishing between them tied in the umbilicum of each of them.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they go out like the one fetus goes out naturally, easily: and they go out by an unpraised exit, as we have said.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If some of them are difficult at the time of parturition and go to the place we mentioned by figures, then care for them as we have said: and let it be due to the subtle thief, and do what it does with facility and tardiness, and act according to every figure with the one who is prepared for him from his ingenuity to salvation.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remembrance of this which is formed in the womb from embryos, and are aborted.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	Sometimes it is formed in the womb of one, and two, and three, and four, and five, and six, and seven, and eight, and more than ten: and I have already heard from a woman who aborted seven, and another fifteen, all formed.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	That is done by the measurement of the glorious wise man.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	Therefore, this entire thing ought to be in the knowledge of the Midwife.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps it will be eager for that similar one: and therefore lays it against that one what is appropriate.
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	Chapter on the Extraction of a Dead Foetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter 76.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you are treating a dead fetus, as I mentioned earlier in the division regarding medication, and it does not leave, and you force it to be operated on with your hand, then it is necessary to consider this.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If the woman is of sound constitution and has not been affected by any of the accidents that are feared to cause her miscarriage, then it is necessary for the woman to be laid on a bed, on her back, with her head lowered, and her legs raised. The attendant should hold her from two sides or lie her down on the bed so that her body is not withdrawn during the extraction of the fetus.
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the woman's mouth with oily, high-quality oils, such as beeswax and flax seeds.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then the midwife should anoint her hands with these oils and beeswax, and then insert it into the woman's mouth with ease.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then she will look for the place where she will make the knots from the fetus, and a suitable place for that.
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Therefore, consider now if the fetus is prepared to descend on its own head, then make knots in its eyes, or in its neck, or in its mouth, or in its palate, or under its beard, or in its shoulder, or in nearby costal regions, and under the hip bones.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If the descent is on its feet, then in the chest and in the ribs of its middle.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it is necessary for her to hold the knot with her right hand: and she should place the fetus between the left fingers of her hand: and she will insert it with her hand with ease, and make a knot in one of those places that I mentioned, until it reaches the womb.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then he shapes another bristle opposite it, or a third one if needed, so that the contraction is equal and does not extend to a part.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then it is extended with an equal extension, and not just along the straight line, but it should also move to all parts so that its exit is as desired, just as happens when a tooth is removed during its extraction.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it is necessary for there to be something in that part so that the extension is softened.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	If that part is held on, then it is necessary for the midwife to apply some oily fingers to it and to insert them from the side so that they rotate with the one being held.
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If the part of the fetus is about to come out, then the bristles should be shifted to another place that is higher up: do this until the whole fetus has come out.
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If the hand is about to come out before the other, and it cannot be reduced because of its constringence: then it is necessary for the cloth to be wrapped around it.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then remove it when it starts to come out completely, either by cutting it or in the joint of the finger, or in the elbow: and it is necessary for you to do the same with the other hand, and in two feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If the head of the fetus is large, or there is a constringence in its coming out, or water is aggregated in its head: then it is necessary for the midwife to insert between her fingers the Spatumile spindle, and to find the head with it and to draw out the water: or she may break it with the instrument called Almisdac, whose form comes with the forms of the other instruments in the head that follows.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Similarly, if the fetus is large-headed in nature, then it is necessary for her to push with the amniotic fluid: or she may take it out with the misdach, as I have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then he takes the bones with his forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	If he goes out the head, and bends at the shoulder: then it is found, until the moisture that is in the chest is expended.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	But if he does not bend, nor yield to the exit: then he will break the head piecewise, according to what is possible for you.
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If it is below the chest, or there is moisture in it: then it is necessary to pierce it, until the moisture flows out of it.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	But if the fetus is above its own feet: then the attraction of it is easy, and the direction of it to the bone of the mother is light.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	But if it is bent at the chest, or the breast: then it is necessary to take it out with the cloth that you have covered over your hand: and find the chest, or the breast, until the moisture that is in them flows out.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	But if the remaining parts are removed, and the head returns: then the midwife inserts her left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	Then if the bone of the mother is open: then she inserts her hand into the bone of the mother, and seeks with it the head, and draws it out with her fingers up to the bone of the mother: then she inserts a nail, or two nails, and draws it out with it.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	But if the bone of the mother is bent, because of the heat that occurs to it: then it does not need to labor over it, but rather it needs at that time to administer an effusion of moist things, such as ointment: and apply the ointment: and she should sit in warm water that softens and moistens.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	But if the fetus is above its own side: then it is possible for it to be equal: then the thing that I said in the fetus of the son is administered.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If that is not possible, then it is fractured in pieces and extracted.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary to not let anything escape from the inside at all.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then administer what I said about hot apostemats which occur in the womb.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If there is a flow of blood, then it should descend into warm applications, and the remainder of the treatment should be given.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have already seen a woman, in whose womb the fetus had died, and then she was impregnated on top of that, and later another fetus died as well.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	It happens to her after a long time, an apostemat in her belly button, which has swelled, until it is opened, and she begins to emit pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I am called to her treatment, and I have been treated for a long time: and the wound is not closed.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I then applied some strong attracting ointments over it: and the bone came out of its place.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then there passed some days, and another bone came out.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I was amazed then, because there is no bone in the womb.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I thought that they were from the bones of the dead fetus.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I then found the bone and extracted many bones from the woman who was in better positions at the time: and she has already done so for a long time, and sends out a little pus from its place.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I did not hold this foreign thing firmly, unless there is knowledge in it, and an aid to the doctor who performs the treatment with his hand from the cure.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	About the necessary forms of instruments in the extraction of the fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	This is the form of the stricture, where the books are equalized by two equal knots at the two ends of two logs.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	However, this Vertigo should be made to be more slender for the stricture: and it should be made either from ebony or from the wood of the bosse.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And the thickness of all woods should be almost like two fingers: and the margin of each of them is almost one finger, and the length of each of them is a palm and half, and in the middle of the two woods there are two additions of the same kind of wood, which have already been firmly fixed in both, whose length is half a palm and a little less, and the width of each of them is almost two fingers or less.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additions are inserted into the mouth of the womb, so that it opens with them when you turn over the two Vertigoes.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the Vertigo that opens the womb.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another form similar to this, but more slender and leaner.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	It should be made from ebony or bosse wood, according to the likeness of the hammer.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	However, at the end of it there should be two additions, as you see here above: and the length of all the addition is almost a palm: and the width of each of them is two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	And when you wish to open the womb with it, then make the woman sit on the bed, with her feet hanging down, and open that which is between her thighs.
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then insert these two additions joined together into the womb: and you are holding the end of the instrument below between her thighs.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, as you do with hammers, equally according to the quantity that you want to open of the womb from the mouth, until the midwife does what she wants.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The form of vertigo is different from what the ancients have said, the form of impelling force by which the fetus is impelled.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The form of Almidace, by which the great head is cut: and it resembles a saw, with teeth at the end, as you see.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And sometimes it is made to close, like the teeth of this form, as you see, which are like the teeth of a saw, by which it is cut and ground.
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The form of Almidace by which the small head is cut.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The form of Uncinus has one spine.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The form of Uncinus has two spines.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The form of a saw, with teeth like a saw, by which the fetal head is cut.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The form of Spatumilis has two ends for cutting off the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The form of two Spatumilis, also of slats.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	This instrument is used for all operations, and the more varied their species, and the better prepared they are at the artisan's disposal, the more suitable it is for its operation, and the higher among men, due to its quantity.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	Therefore, do not despise any of these instruments, as it may be prepared at your disposal.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	It is inexcusable for the need of these instruments.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	¶ On the extraction of the second child.
Caput LXXVIII.	Head LXXVIII.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second child is held during childbirth, then it is necessary to apply strong remedies to keep its hunger.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make it sneeze with condiments: and tightly hold your hand on its mouth, and the nostrils of its own.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If then it goes out through this, it is good.
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then take the cauldron, and perforate it in the cover: and put into it herbs unfolding the mouths of the matricaries, such as calamus, rue, and anemonium, and camomile, and sage, and linen hemp, and centaury: take all these herbs, or some of them, and submerge them with water, and place them over the fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then place a dish of barley over the cover of the cauldron, and another end in the mouth of the matricary: and hold it until it becomes saturated with the moisture of the matricary.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make it hiss, as I have said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The second part will be easier.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If however it remains after this treatment and does not go away: then advise the obstetrician to dip her hand in oil of sweet almonds, or a strong tincture of mucilage.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then she should introduce it into the uterus and seek with it the second part.
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When she finds it, then take it up and extend it a little at a time.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If however it is annexed to the deep matricary, then she should introduce her hand according to what we have said until she finds the second part and withdraws it a little at a time so that the matrix does not fall on the strong attraction: in fact, it should be turned with ease to the right and left side: then add to the quantity of attraction.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	The matricary obeys at this point and is loosened and drawn away from the adhesion.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	If the mouth of the matricary is contracted as we have already mentioned: treat it with steam and the medicine of the cauldron with herbs.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If, however, he does not proceed with the others that we have mentioned, then be careful not to tire himself out over this in the course of the repeated extractions.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	Indeed, it should be that whatever is inserted into the tooth of the mother, it should be placed in the woman's house.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then apply it with the ointment of Tetrapharmacian.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	For it will decay it after days, and it will dissolve, and it will be withdrawn.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	Indeed, when it decays, it should be leeched with that bad smell to the stomach and head, and it will hurt the weak one.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	Therefore, it should be that the suffumigations suitable for that are administered.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	However, some of the ancient ones have already found a suffumigation of nasturtium and wine vinegar.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The form of the instrument by which it is suffumed, a woman at the retention of Secondus and during menstruation.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be made from the inside of a cataplasm, or from honey: and let its wide end be placed over the fire: and the suffumigation should be placed over the prunes: hold it until the suffumigation is consumed: and then another one.
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	¶ About the treatment of Ani not pierced.
Caput LXXIX.	Head LXXIX.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born, and their heads, Ani of them which is not pierced, which the poor woman has already made small with a needle.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	Therefore, it should be that the midwife pierces it with her own finger: and if not, she pierces it with the sharp sponge: and let her be careful not to touch it with the leg.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then place over it a fattened wool in wine and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it is cured.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If then you fear that the wound is suppurating, then place a septic needle in the hole for several days, and remove it when the boy wants to stool.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And already there is suppuration of the wound also from the consolidation of the wound or from postmortem changes.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	Therefore it is necessary to cut that consolidation, then treat with the one we said from treatment and the needle.
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	¶ About the treatment of fistulas that occur in the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Chapter 80.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas which occur in the lower part are Nodules and Enlargements which occur near the deformed anus: or in a single part of one part: it is either a single fistula or several.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When that nodule becomes old, it opens, and white moisture or thin pus comes out of it.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes there are penetrating ones from these fistulas.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore the penetrating ones are known by that which comes out of evacuation, and moisture, when it is used in weak evacuation: and perhaps it comes out from those wombs.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And they are fistulas when they are in the space of penetrating ones until to the ute and to the virgin's meatus.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are penetrating until to the joint of the thigh, and to the nodule of the tail.
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From that by which it is known that the fistula is penetrating to the anus, and even not penetrating, is, that you put your finger into the anus: and you put your finger into the subtle one into the fistula from air or iron: when there is no tortuosity.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	And if there is tortuosity in it, then you put into it a finger tentam from the knee subtle, or a pilum from the hair of horses, until you feel the tentam, or a pilum in your thumb.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not perceive the whole truth, nor does anything come out of the hole, nor breath, nor offspring as I said: then you know that it is not penetrable: therefore for the treatment.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	When the fistula is penetrable up to the bladder or to the urinary sediment: then its meaning is the exit of urine from it, and its prohibition for this so that the place can be healed with medicines.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If indeed it is penetrable up to the hip joint, or to the knee: then its sign is that it may pass through and try until it comes out, if there is no tortuosity up to the knee: and an finding of pain in the circumference of the part, and that pus always issues from it: and that it does not please in it any medicine, nor is it consolidated with ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And in all these fistulas that are penetrable, there is no cure at all: and the cure of them is a labor and shame to him, from whom it is made.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	In those however which are not penetrable and not old, hope for a cure with a bandage: according to what I tell you, and I have proved it: and it is that you lie weakly between your hands on his back: and extend his thighs above his hip bones, and his hips are inclined towards his belly.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then he will introduce the introducer into the fistula if there is tortuosity in it, until you know where it may pass.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If however he feels it weak around the anus, then it is necessary for you to introduce your finger into the anus.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If then you feel with your finger that it has passed through itself already, detected, but not between your finger and the thumb, or between your flesh and the skin: then you know certainly that it is penetrable: therefore you do not labor in it, because it is not its cure, as I said.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They said nevertheless because it is cured in some men by flesh, and through the medicine that is expected to be applied for strength, it is, as has been said before, that a fine needle is made hot and then inserted into the fistula until it goes around the anus.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then repeat this twice or three times until you know that all those added and filtered flesh have become ashlike, which is similar to the feather of a pen, because it has been said.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then treat that with linen wraps dipped in butter until those ashlike flesh comes out, then treat it with ointments that generate and solidify flesh.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If it is cured, that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, then it will never be cured with another treatment.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if it comes out and does not go around your thumb, which is in the anus, and it is between it and the spilled flesh from the flesh, or sifac: and you see the fistula in it that follows the surface of the skin, then dry the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and you cut with the skin as you try it that is in the fistula until it goes around the extremity of the tryout, and the tryout is freed and falls.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then clean those filtered flesh that is similar to the feather of a pen, so that nothing remains of them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however blood does not come out of you, and it splits between you and the operation that you do so that those flesh can leave: then better what is done, and more beneficial for your strength, to cauterize it with fire or with sharp medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For the cauterization with fire brings good associations, adds the ashlike of those flesh, and the separation of blood and the drying of moisture.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then that care, when the liniments have been applied to honey or thoroughly tritured wool, until the spot emits pus, and those burned flesh comes out in pus.
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then the care then the heel when the ointments that are forming hard flesh, and are those medicines in which there is stimulation and exfoliation: and they are the remedies in which there is stimulation and exfoliation.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	For when they rest, then it is already cured: and there is no fear of repetition.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	However, if the fistula has already become inflamed up to the depth of the anus, and is extended beyond the excess of the body: then insert your finger into the anus, and explore with it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If then you feel a trial, and there is flesh or blood between you, and near to penetration: then there is no operation in that, except according to the confidence and hope.
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	That is, because it is given in that one of three modes: either to burn it itself, as we said: or to leave it, until you have obtained cohesion of this, so that it may be possible for you to insert the liniment and the cure from the nearest.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed much with the cut, so as not to injure the surrounding thigh, and there may be an exit from the least excrement without desire.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for that which we have said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps it will be cured: or extend it and cleanse it after you have removed it as far as the anus, as we said, or when you try, or with another sharp edge.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then cleanse those flesh filtered that are in the cut, until where you can with scrutiny.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then dare to restoration of the wound of the whole with the cut, and the opening above where it is consolidated: and there will remain the fistula open in the inner part of the anus, and it will be less on the weakest.
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	When the fistula is ready, it is done as follows: and when you insert your finger into the fistula, it is found on the side of the anus near the surface of the body, with the skin and the margin of the anus: then take the perforated end, which is like a lancet of Aleskef, that is, the preparation of coria, according to this form.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And insert the thread into it, wound around five times, approximately.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	Then insert the tentaculum with the thread into the fistula, until the cohesion of it is reached.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If then it passes through the margin of the anus internally near, then take out the thread from that hole: so that you can insert your finger into the anus, and take out the end of the thread, and gather together both ends of the thread simultaneously: and tie them together, and let it hang for one or two days: and as much as the thread may penetrate into the flesh, tie it firmly, until the flesh that is between the two ends of the thread falls off and drops out: then care for the wound, until it heals and becomes sound.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	If the opening of the fistula is not easily penetrated, then make it penetrate in whatever way is most convenient for you, unless it is very deep.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For you do not have a knife to make it in order not to cut it.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then make it as we have said, until it heals.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	The form of the Spatumilis spikes, from which the fistula is made, whose edge is sharp and the other part is not sharp, so that it does not penetrate what is not necessary, as you see.
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	¶ About the suture of hemorrhoids, from which blood flows from their incision: and care for the cuts.
Caput LXXXI.	Head 81.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are two types of varices.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	Or they are within the anus, resembling carbon or prunes, or almost like grains of salt.
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And among them are small and large ones, and blood runs constantly from them, it is always the same, and there are many of them.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the anus and at its extremities.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	However, those that are outside the anus are of few moistures, from which water white runs, or a little blood flows continuously: and they are according to the color of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the treatment of it that is inside the anus is like that of a weak person who has been beaten with an ass's hide: and it is expressed until it goes out of the anus, and becomes visible to you.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore, also suspend them with gut or hold them with your own grease.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut them at their roots.
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	If they are not held by the gut, because of their moisture and their own softness: then take them with a rough cloth, or with a brush made from wool, and pull them out with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut them, and apply some warm ointment to them after cutting, so that they hold their place at the site of cauterization.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what is prescribed in the chapter on cauterization.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then take care of them with the rest of the treatment until they heal.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	If the anus does not yield to the exit of the stool, then apply a weak ointment in which there is a small biting in the clister, so that it may be easy to expel with what is inside the anus, and it will yield quickly when it is expelled.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If however the warts are outside the anus, then they are easier to remove, more accessible: and it is best to capture them with your nail, or with a razor, and cut them off.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then take care of them in the manner we have said, until they heal.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And if someone dislikes cutting with iron, then it is necessary to apply a suture to them according to this method.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take the thread enveloped in the wart, and insert it into the anus.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then remove the wart from above, and make it penetrate with the needle into the root of it from the other side: and envelop the two ends of the thread with the point of the needle in the lower part, making them parallel: and fasten the wart firmly.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then cut the thread, and remove the wart.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the warts, and let one out of them: nor take your own, lest it causes a surplus of blood from that one.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place a cloth soaked in rose or cinnamon oil on the anus, and place the wart on top of it: and instruct the patient to remain still.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let it fall off, until it falls off.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When the warts fall off, take care of them with ointments and further treatment until they heal.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	¶ Regarding the treatment of Fissures.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Indeed they often occur due to the dryness of the feces and the constriction of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When they become too large and do not respond to medical treatment: then it is necessary to make them moist with the points of salt or with your nail, until they become soft, and remove the upper part of the cortex which prevents them from being consolidated.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then take care of them until they are consolidated according to what is appropriate.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If they do not consolidate, then repeat them with a more severe reasoning than the first, until they bleed much and then let them care for them until they heal.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	De cure of Alimari for wounds that are opening and those that are not, and of ants and termites.
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter 82.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that Alimari is only a round node according to the color of the body, similar to the hair clinging to it, and it occurs throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and fingers: and it causes pain during walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Therefore, it should be cut off where it clings to the hair, and held with thorns, or with a razor, and it should be uprooted from its root.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then treat that: and if you wish to cauterize it according to what is said in the chapter of that wound.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	From ants, however, the small and sharp ones are a single prominence, rough, filtered, round above the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they often occur in the hands of children.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	The treatment of it is to extend the ant, and cut it off: or pull it off with a thread from silk: or with wool until it falls off.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what was said with fire, or with sharp medicine: and already the Atheli opening and not opening wounds are removed with the instrument that I will say.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	Formica is also a small and rough prominence, large, on the surface of the body, crawls into the valley of cold water: and when it finds the cold, it feels like a sting of the ant in its whole body, and it happens most in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	The treatment for this is to take a quill from a goose or a strong swan's feather, and place it over the formicacia until the circle of the quill from its parts holds.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then roll your hand with the quill, until the part that is in the circumference of the formicacia is separated: and place it in deep flesh, and dig out the formicacia from the root of it.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, do this with the quill of copper or iron, according to this shape.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	The upper part of the quill should be drawn up to the height, being wrapped around it, so that it rises above the grasp of the finger and its rolling.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish to cauterize the formicacia according to what was said in the chapter of cauterization about Athel,
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	¶ About the shapes of instruments which are used for Clisteries in diseases of the Anus, and for the venting of the bowels, and for the relief of colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When a Clistery is made from silver or gold, or from melted bronze, or from hammered iron.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes it is made from these instruments of small and large sizes, according to those which are used in them.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Therefore that which is given for the care of young children should be small; and of those whose anus is weak or painful, so also should be their Clistery.
Clistere magnum.	Large Clistery.
Cistere paruum.	Small Clistery.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The head of the Clistery, that is, where the uter is tied, should be broad according to this manner: and there should be a distinction so that it may be placed on the uter as you see, and the lower part of its opening which enters into the anus should be round, that is, not open, soft, gently drawing towards the subtlety: and in one side there should be two foramens, and in the other side one.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	The size of the foramen should be according to the size of the teeth, and smaller in larger ones, and they should be placed in the one in which medicines are made from animal secretions: either from the paw of a small animal, such as the squirrel, which has a form similar to the small toe: whose root is a single thumb.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And let there be holes multiplied as it rotates, and let there be a space that is between the grossness of all the digits.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert a thick thread into those holes, perhaps from ten threads, or about it, and gather it with the udder like that of the squirrel.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When the udder is placed on it, the membrane should be tied at the head of the clitoris between two distinct constrictions of strong force.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then tie the membrane with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the form of the circle depicted here, and the holes.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of tying it with it is: to fill the udder, or the medicine, which is heated according to the tolerance of the weak: and be careful not to make it hot or cold vagina.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the weak one will lie down on its back, and will raise its legs to the upper parts: and put under it a blanket, that is, the layer over which men lie, or a linen cloth.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then anoint the end of the membrane with oil, or with almond oil, or with Greek mucilage, or similar.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the anus with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then the midwife will take the udder with both hands of her, and express it with force, until all that is in the membrane is emptied into the intestine.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then take out the membrane, and raise the weak legs to the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If medicine considers it to be the end, then let her hold as much as she can.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with her all night, it is better for the incision.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If you, however, apply the bandage to his ailments of the fluid, and he hastens its end: then reapply the bandage until it is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids in the anus, or painful apostemata, then the bandage should be a fine, soft one, made of cloths on which children are bandaged.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this should be the form of the fine bandage over which the cuticle is tight.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	¶ On the treatment of head wounds without breaking the bones.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head LXXXIIII.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already spoken of the treatment of wounds that were suitable for division in the division, and I will now tell you the treatment of those wounds with my hand and with medicines according to the complement.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say then that wounds are divided according to the kind of wound and according to the place where the bone falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore, by which wounds are made, they are like the fall of a stone: or the cut of an ensign, or a knife: or the blow with a lance, or a piece of wood, or an arrow: and similarly from many things.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	However, wounds that are made according to the place of the body are like this: such as the bone which falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or the ear: and similar ones from these parts.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am telling you about the treatment of some wounds so that I can lay down reasoning and order for the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds: for the reminder of the writers will not be at the beginning of the third chapter.
Dico ergo.	I say therefore.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wedge occurs in the head and there is no fracture of the bones: then consider whether it is from a fall or similar, and whether it has merely scratched the skin: and if it is a large wound, and you fear the outcome of the treatment on the weak one: then immediately perform a cranial phlebotomy: and do not delay this: and remove it from the blood according to the strength of its power: if it does not prevent something from phlebotomy, especially if it is blood that is escaping from the wound.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be on the opposite side of the wound.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And beware of the weak one being overfed, and with rich foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If something prevents reduction, then it is less from food, and it will not approach flesh, nor wounds.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place over the wound if it happens to the head a hot application, a warm ointment in rose oil alone, or with wine that is steeped.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If you are careful about the hot application from the wound, then place over the head if it is fresh with its own blood, and has not changed the air, the boy I will tell you about in a moment: and if it has changed the air, then place over it some ointment until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If the head is large, or it is from an incision with a sword, and similar: and the lips are not gathered together with the flaps, then gather them together with the suture, according to what I will tell you about the wounds of the lungs about their sutures.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If the wound has already been detected from the bone, and it hangs down, and there is no hold on it except in a small suspender: then cut it off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then he treats the wound with medicines and restores the hard flesh in its place, and instructs the patient to eat foods rich in nutrients such as the head and cooked wheat, until it is soft enough to be chewed, and similar foods.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If I find putrefaction in the skin and it does not adhere to the bone, then I will cut out the putrid whole and remove it, and then I will treat it.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	However, if there is an artery or a vein from which blood flows in these wounds, and it is not cut out by medicines, then I will investigate the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If I find that it has not been cut, then I will dry it with salt or tie it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the need arises to cause it when it does not heal what I said, then I will cauterize it until the blood is cut out.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	However, if these wounds are small and simple, then the treatment of them is easy, as this child does to it: for he consolidates it before he changes the air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Mode of the child's healing.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.
