Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But that which is above the opening of the cavity, is the one that moves every hour, so as to go out that which is collected in it from the pus: and so you may know whether that which runs out from it is much, or little: or digested, or not digested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you again consider the place of the cavity of that member, whether the lord of it feels pain in it, or there is no pain in it, or whether there is an apostematic swelling in it, or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When you thus apply your medicine in this manner and see the matter which is passing over the orifices of the Sinus, then you know that the Sinus has already adhered or is approximating its adhesion: therefore, dissolve it in the morning or on the third day: and when you have dissolved the gum, then turn the other side of the bandage and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If however, something comes out of the Sinus after a long period of time, then do not despair of its adhesion, for the healing of it approaches, because there are men who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrary to it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however, something comes out of the Sinus after many days of a badly digested pus, then you know that the Sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If however, the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and prolonged: then add to the drying of the medicines, let the physicians make them so that they are humid in their substance and in their virtue, as the ointment Dyafinicon, when added to it, has superfluity of addition from the zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last treatment that is given, it is best to take the ointment Dyafinicon, and dissolve it with rose oil, and renew it over the old wine equal in substance to it.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then close it up with that, and use it yourself.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it already does a similar action when there is no Dyafinicon ointment present for you, honey, when you mix it, until it thickens, and you use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and frankincense, and olibanum: beat them all together, and make this thinner over the melted wax while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then tie a thread around the wound, and make it as tight as possible. And when the thread is soaked in honey until it becomes thick, and then apply the honeyed thread to the wound, and place the pan beneath it, and tie it up.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when longarista is administered, and the heavenly lily roots, and the lily itself, and the herb's flour, and the centaury: then it will be beneficial.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Either use them in their simple form, or mixed together, grind them, and mix the crumbs with honey: and apply the honey to the wound, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the wound prolongs and is not healed by this treatment: then you know that there is corruption in its depth: or it has made an impression on the bones, or on other hard parts, or on the ligaments: then treat it according to the treatment for fistulas, as was previously stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Regarding the care of Panaritius and the trimmed nail, and the addition of a cut to the digit, and the section:
Caput XCI.	Head 51.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritius is a wart that is born under the nail of the hand or foot, and may be born in other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it prolongs and is neglected in its treatment, and becomes a wart of hot warts: or it corrupts and emits pus until it corrodes the nail root: and perhaps it corrupts it entirely, and perhaps it spreads the corruption to the bone, until it has an unpleasant odor: and it becomes the end of the digit flat, and its color becomes black.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you are treating it, if the wart is not cured by the division and your treatment does not fit: then it is necessary to cut with iron all the remaining excess from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the cauterization of the wound is on the side.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the mouth is sound, and the nail and nail bed are also sound, and the additions of the nail begin to compress the flesh to the interior, and begin to prick it, and hurt it: then it is necessary to place a fine gold powder under the angle of the nail that pricks the flesh, and press it upwards: and cut through the remaining flesh with ease, and place on top of it what remains of the medicines burning and corroding, until it is all removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for that with ointments until it is healed.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If corruption has already begun to prick the mouth, then it is necessary to cut through that mouth and take it out: for the mouth does not heal while the corrupted part remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see burning and corruption to increase in the finger, then cut it off according to the memory of the nail that was previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, an abrasion or impact occurs on the nail, and pain arises in it, then it is necessary to first use a vein let into the primary one.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then scrape off the nail with an acid-free cut, transferred from above to the mouth.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard against the section reaching the flesh that is under the nail, for you are causing it to happen by this over the primary painful one, and it will be a cause of adding flesh to the place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with what soothes the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	But the finger added to which pain is born in some human hands, perhaps it is entirely fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and some of them are born from the root of the joint, or it is a birth of its nails in some nodes of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in certain nails of fingers, does not move; and he who is born at the joint of a finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	His whose meat is from them, the section of it is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	What is, as you hit yourself at the root of it with a spatula wide.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But whose birth is in the root of the joint, it is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	So avoid its cutting.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In him however who is born at the tip of a finger, it is necessary to cut into the primary meat of its round incision up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then cut the bone with one of those convenient saws for that.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the consolidation which happens to fingers is often due to the man's birth, that is, born with him, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from combustion of fire, and such.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	So it is necessary to leave that consolidation until the fingers return according to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place a ligature between them, or linen infused in rose oil: so that they do not consolidate quickly, and separate it between them; or place a thin silver sheet between them, until the place consolidates according to what is appropriate.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if a consolidation happens to certain fingers with the palm, then cut that consolidation according to what is prepared and becomes suitable for the figure of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ Of the cutting of the Vice.
Caput XCII.	Caput XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	The veins are entangled, thick, full of superfluous melancholic disorders that happen in many parts of the body: and the most common of them is in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk and labor, and carry.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	It is necessary then that you administer an enema of the body from black bile several times with a strong enema.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then make a phlebotomy on the patient's basilica.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these, when iron is used, is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Their wounds are to be cured so that blood is drawn, and black blood is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another method is to make the vein rise and draw out all of it.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of this is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	The thigh is first embroccated with hot water, until the thick, feces-like blood is dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the weak thigh from the upper part of the hip to the lower part of the knee.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then shave the wound in one place, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then extract, that is, draw out the blood in your hand from the lower part of the thigh up to the top, and the upper part must be treated with a phlebotomy first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then shave the nail until it goes out of the blood quantity that you see is sufficient, and that the weakness can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie the nail: and command him to abstain from food that produces black bile: and repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins are full, and do not harm the weak one.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The extraction of this is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Rub the weak thigh if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then put it in the bath: or embrocate it in the thigh of the patient with hot water, until it reddens and the veins become swollen, or exercise a strong exercise on it if there is no bath nearby, until the member becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then scrape the skin in a straight line along its length: either at its end near the knee, or in its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hair follicles and scrape off the sweat from all sides until it becomes apparent to touch: and this is at the appearance of that which you see red turn to black and downward.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it comes out of the skin, you will see it as if it were a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert the radium under it, until when it is clean and comes out of the skin: suspend it with a black eyelash, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then scrape another section near that one in three fingers' length.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from its upper part until it becomes apparent.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then clean it with radium as you have done, and suspend it with a black eyelash as you have done at the beginning.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then scrape another section or several more if you need them for that.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then clean it and cut the last section near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you pull it out from the higher or all higher sections until it comes out completely: then cut it off.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you to pull out and clean: then insert a needle with strong twofold wire, and bind it, and pull it out: or insert the radium under it: and roll your hand over all parts until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And take care that it does not cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it cuts, it becomes difficult for you to clean it gently and it comes out on the weakest part of it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you pull it all out: then put on the place of the wound a piece of soft wool dipped in wine and rose oil, or rose oil: and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine is contracted, having a winding which it is to be bent towards the parts, and is not as we said according to straightness: then it is necessary to find on it for all the tortuosity of its part, and the location of its involution.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with gut, until you lift it entirely: and be careful at your section, over it not to tear the skin, or wounds: for it will be difficult to lift it up, or pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore keep your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The shape of the wound where the vine is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of the blind man's wound.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not like the other wounds, nor is it sharp at its extremities, so as not to wound the skin: and it has a broad bending, but it is gentle: for if it were subtle, it would tear the skin with its subtility: indeed it has superfluous grossness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	The extraction of the vein of the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Head 13.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs on earth, like Azizi, and the Arab earth, and in hot dry lands, few tender ones, that is, in which there is no growth of herbs or trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Indeed its generation is from putrefaction which happens under the skin, like that which happens inside the bodies of snakes and ascaris worms, and the worms generated between the skin and the flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein's growth is that which happens in the leg inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then it becomes inflamed.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to exit from the location of this cauterization, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When the extremity of that part appears, then it is necessary to suspend the lead over the entire thickness of the lead, whose weight is equal to two drachms of the kilogram, up to two drachms and the same leaf: and let go the suspended lead from the finger.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever something exits from that part towards the outside, suspend that over the lead, and the same leaf.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is extended to a great extent, then cut off a part of it, and suspend the remaining part.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it off before it has completely exited.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it off, it contracts, and enters into the flesh: and it causes an aposteme, and putridity in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to treat it carefully and draw it out gradually, until it has completely exited from its last part, and nothing remains of it in the body: and from this same Vena it exits in some men who are five palms long and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And it has already been relieved to me, because it has exited the man from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it is cut off from you at the time of your medicine: then insert the radium into its foramen, and perforate it with a long foramen, while the body, until all that is in it of matter is expelled: and administer putridity to the place with medicines on certain days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of the cure of the aposteme.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this same Vena sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and many wounds happen to it, and it exits from all its wounds a branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, the cure itself, as we have said in division and what has been said earlier.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Regarding the section on worms generated under the skin, and it is called bouina's disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Head 138.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called in a certain land in our country Aegritudo bouina: for it often happens among worms, and is a small one, which is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it goes throughout the body, ascending and descending: and is shown to the sense during walking of its member to its member, until it breaks wherever it breaks into the skin place, and exits.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from putrefaction of some humans.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	So do worms and snakes, that is, pinworms, and ascarids in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they fear from its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it itself goes through the body, and rises to the head, and wanders to its place: then perhaps it may open in it, and exit, and destroy the eye: and this often happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it, and take it out, then this is not done unless at walking of its member, and sense of its own.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary to tie what is above it, and that which is under it with a strong constriction bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and take it out from it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is deeply inserted in the flesh, and you do not find it: then place over the place cauterization with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than what is feared, is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If then you see him already inflamed in the head near the eye, then draw a good tight fringe under it.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then scrape it off from it, and remove it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that he use weak cleansing of his body, when the physicians are putting down bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him avoid foods generating putrefaction in him.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	¶ About the cut for the illness of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Head 45.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called Nakir in our land: and it is a pain that happens in some members, and then it is changed from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have seen it, according as I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I am called to an old woman in some houses.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she takes off her arm, and I see a small inflammation in the flesh of her arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour she has passed, I see one inflammation going up with the fire, as if it were a child going up to her shoulder, which is higher than it can be: so that it is like silver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore the pain has departed from that place, and it has been fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat an hour, and it ran into the rest of the body, until it had inflamed another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was moving in all her body, according as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	Therefore I was amazed at the rapid change of its member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had not seen this disease in my eyes in this manner before.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	Nevertheless I have seen many who found the pain to change from one member to another, and I did not see it as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not think this to be the case, unless it is because she was one of those who were detected by the dry parts of the body as being of the nature of the ovary: hence it appears to the senses that her soul has been changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and in the moist bodies of the hidden ovaries.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you are treating her and she feels the pain of that: then if it is apparent to you with your eye, as we have said, then tighten above it, and below it quickly: and dry above it, until it leaves that attached soul: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you do not see it with your eyes: then treat it with the movement of the body, and with that which expels the souls, and with those that carve them with the foul pills, and the pills of serapin, and such like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Regarding the extraction of the Sagittarius:
Caput XCVI.	Head 56.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	The Sagittarius is diversified according to its species and the locations where it falls from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	The diversity of theirs is: for out of them are those which have great and small points, and sharp ones, and soft ones.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And out of them are those which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And out of them are those which have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And out of them are those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which are according to the parts where they fall, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or if the parts be from the principal parts, as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lungs, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the uterus, and such like.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any of these members, and you see signs of death which I will tell you later, then it is necessary for you to make an extraction of that arrow from them, for death follows the part in which it is, in many different ways.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see these signs of evil, and the arrow is not hidden deep in the member, then take out the same, and care for the groove.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the arrow falls into the brain, and pierces the mouth, and comes out of the siphon which is over the brain, it is: for there happen from that wound, a coma, a scotomy, a trembling, a redness in the eyes, an inflation, a red tongue, a spasm, a mixture of the intellect, and vomiting of choler.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will issue from the nostrils, or from the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps the speech is abscised, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there issues from the wound site, a white humidity similar to pus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it issues from there, like water of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If then you see these signs, then abstain from treatment, and remove the arrow if it does not issue.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	However, the signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left breast: and it feels as if it is fixed in a hard thing, not in a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a motion similar to that of the pulse: and it runs from the groove black blood.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows that cold at the extremities, and a cold sweat, and syncope.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Therefore you know that death has come far from doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	When the arrow pierces the lung, blood starts to spurt from the wound, and the surrounding tissue becomes red and swollen.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	He exhales a large, high breath, seeking the cold air's attraction.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the heart, which is in the chest: then it is near the ribs: and there is a great sighing with painful breathing, with a sigh: and all the limbs of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach: perhaps something undigested from food will exit through the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the belly, and is embedded in it: something fecal will exit through the wound, or dung, or already split intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope for its cure, nor in removing the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder, and urine exits: and something comes out from it to the outside, and the pain is more severe on the weakest part: then you know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining parts, such as the face, neck, throat, windpipe, support, and vertebrae of the back, and the knee, leg, and foot, are healed according to various dispositions: when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve, and there is no venomous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen these arrows, so that you understand through this about your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because an arrow fell into the tearful eye of a certain man, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I drew it out from the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and it did not harm him in his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which fell into the fat of his eye beneath his lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I could not catch it from its tip except with the very tip of my finger, where it adhered to the wood of the bow: and it was a large arrow from the bow of the Turcomen, with a soft iron, in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore the Jew is healed, and there does not happen to the eye of his an accident evil.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabian arrow, and it is this to which they have ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Therefore I held it above the same two guides: and it was already under the throat of his.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	Therefore I was able to touch it with it, until I extracted it: and the Christian is healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from the urine of a man, which fell into the belly of his: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed, and nothing had changed in his situation, I held it above the same arrow: and I touched it with my fingers, and extracted it: and he was healed, and there did not happen to him an accident evil.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man whose arrow fell on the back of his, and the wound was closed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years had passed, the arrow was pulled out from the root of his leg.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman whose arrow fell into her belly, and the wound was closed over it, and the arrow remained inside of it, and nothing had changed in her situation, and the woman did not find any harm to herself in any of the natural operations of her.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	I saw another man who had a shaft fall on his face: and the sole of his foot was healed, and he found little pain in him, and such like many others.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	I took a shaft from the king's man, which had fallen on his middle of the nose and was leaning towards the right side almost: and the shaft was hidden completely.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I am called to take care of him after the fall of the shaft for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the healed sole of the shaft.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I tried to find it with my fingers and did not feel it, and he himself found the puncture and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that that was the end of the shaft.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I applied the plaster to the place with the plaster that attracted virtue and digestion, confident among me that it would be the place to be cut, and I wanted to see a sign of the shaft so that I could cut it: and it did not happen in the place, meaning that the shaft had followed the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I applied the plaster to it for many days: and no accident happened, and the sole of his foot was healed in the meantime: and he remained weak from the extraction of that space for some days, until he felt the shaft one day within his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I applied sharp medicine to it, for many days until it was open: and when I tried to touch it, and I felt the thin end of the shaft that clings to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine, until the end of the shaft was visible clearly: and it passed by me after that space of about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then, after the wound had been amputated and I was able to insert my fingers into it, move it around, and it did not obey the exit: then I did not stop refining and engineering over it with such methods as those of the craftsmen, until I succeeded in removing it on a certain day with forceps made to appear suitable for the form of their ends, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I repaired the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	Indeed, doctors also judge that the nasal cartilage does not heal.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore, I repaired it again, and the amputated part was consolidated and healed, and it became strong in frail health, and nothing harmed it at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	I will tell you the quality of extracting a certain arrow: so that you can place this rule and meaning over the one I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts and distinctions of this art are not understood with narration: nor is it understood by that book, and a wise craftsman compares little with much: and when he finds that which is present, he compares it with that which is absent: and he discovers a new operation and instrument among the descent of things extraneous to this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say that arrows do not come out of the limbs in which they are fixed, except through two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or from the opposite side of the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which is coming out from where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding into the fleshy place, and it is attracted and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey the exit from the hour in which it falls, then it is necessary to let it go for a few days until the flesh around it putrefies: and the attraction of it will disappear, and its coming out.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	If a bone is imagined to be in the way, and does not yield to your will, then release it for a few days: and then try again with attraction and motion every day until it passes.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not yield to your will after several days, then it is necessary to drill holes all around the bone in that bone with a sharp point, until the arrows enlarge.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it towards you and remove it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however, the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head and has already pierced one of the cerebral veins, and it appears that some of the previously mentioned accidents have occurred: then cease from attraction of the arrow, and release it, until it is equal in that day.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow pierces the skull, then death is not prolonged to him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed only in the bones, but does not pierce even to the skull: and it remains weak for a few days, and no such accidents occur: then let ingenuity be used in the attraction of the arrow and its removal.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however, it is fixed firmly and does not yield to attraction: then apply a sharp point around the arrow as I have described: then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however, the arrow is already hidden in the body, and it is hidden and concealed from the senses: then seek it out when you attempt.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If however, you feel it: then draw it towards you with some instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If however, you cannot get over it because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in the deep part: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein: then find something above it, until the vein enlarges, and it is possible to remove the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If the parts that hold the ears are free, then loosely fasten the flesh all around them from every side and every part of your skill, and also the skills you cannot reach beyond the flesh of the ear, and its bending, until it separates.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	When you perform the extraction of the arrow, wherever it is, then use a twisting motion of your hand with the needles to all parts, until it separates: and with the finest subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and make it difficult for you to attract it, and its own extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot remove it at once, then let it be for a few days until the putrefied parts around it are removed.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then try it again: for if it makes a contrary flow of blood, then administer what I said in the chapter of its treatment: and guard your virtue from incision, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And use all the skill you can to remove the arrow: and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I will tell you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that when you are pulling out the arrow, it should be weak according to its figure, according to which was at the case of the arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more difficult.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow that is going out from the opposite part of another thing, or already goes out from it something to the outside: or makes a bulge at the end of the arrow through the sense of the upper part of the skin near by, and you see it prominent: then cut over it, and let the section be according to the quantity that is taken in the nails.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then he draws it: for it is itself easy to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is retained in the bone, then turn your hand according to the roundness of the bone, until the arrow points into the bone and enlarges itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: release it for a few days: then try again until it goes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow is of wood in it, then push it with the arrow.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the wood falls, and you wish to give it force: then insert the sharp-pointed instrument into it, so that the sharpness of its point reaches the end of the arrow: then push it with the arrow.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is sharp-pointed, then push it with the arrow as you insert it into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow is made to point by this.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut all the flesh in which the poison is, if it is possible for you to do this.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for it as it comes near to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling into the heart, or into the belly, or into the loin, or into the side: and it is near to that which you touch with your nail, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut it, and take care not to cut into the poison, or the nerve, and pull it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then clean the wound, if you see, and care for that until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the finger, by which they take out the arrows.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let the ends be similar to the face and jaw, which are made like a horn: when they take hold of the arrow above it, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are of various kinds, great and small, and medium, according to the magnitude of the arrow, and its flexibility, and the width of the wound, and the tightness of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the impelling cone.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the deaf cone.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the extremity of the deaf cone, like a radius, so that its introduction into the conical cavity is made smooth, and it is impelled with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of the impelling cone of this cone is a cone like a feather: so that its introduction into the arrowhead is made smooth, and it is impelled with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Regarding Bloodletting of the Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head 47.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	Bloodletting veins, which are customary in the body, are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Out of which in the head there are sixteen: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called the two Herbs: and two arteries, which are apparent in two temporal bones: and two veins, which are in two lacrimal bags of both eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and the prepared vein in the middle of the forehead: and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Glands, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins, which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins, which are in the lower lip of the mouth.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins, which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins, which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	However, the veins that are bloodlet from the arms are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the cephalic vein, and it is from the side of the head: and it is called the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the black one.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the median vein, and it is composed of the branch of the Basilic vein, and the branch of the cephalic vein: and it is called the great vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	The basilica is placed on the side of the domestic house, and it is also known as Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And he calls it a vile ventriloquist.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the tendon of the arm is placed on the thin one: and it is that which is used for phlebotomy, and it is that which appears above the thumb with a clear manifestation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the salute is a vile one that is between the annulus and the minimum: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three viles in the wrist and in the foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is that which is under the thumb curved from the side, with a silk band.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second one is the saphenous: and its location is at the heel with the side of the domestic house.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vile Ness is and its location is at the heel with the side of the domestic house.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And there are three other similar ones in the wrist like these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Regarding the phlebotomy of the two vines after the Aures.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	However, the phlebotomy of the two vines that are after the Aures is an old treatment for catars, hemangiomas, and saffras, and an old wound on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is according to what I say.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is that the head of the weak one is extended: and the head of his occipital is at the location of the two vines with a good hard rubbing with a rough cloth.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the weak one ties his neck with a cord until the two vines appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are after the Aures in two places of depressed heads.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore, seek them with your finger and where you feel the pulse of these under your finger, mark them with a candle.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the vial for phlebotomy, and that is called the Incident one.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the skin until the phlebotomy pierces the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then make an incision in your arm and hand with the vein and skin above, and make a cut in the vein with the incision incident one.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision should be the length of two fingers, or approximately this: and make it come out of the blood as much as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie it with threads, and let it go until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And this has already been mentioned at the beginning of the book, and that of its cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	¶ About the phlebitis of two arteries in time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	However, the two arteries that are in the two phlebitis of the surgery are the oldest: and shave it rough, and make deep cuts: and let the course of the excessive flow of the sharp blood to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the phlebitis is according to what I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The weak neck of his arm should be tied tightly, until the two veins are visible by their appearance: and you will show the pulse of them with your thumb.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then signs will be shown when burned.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then make an incision in the skin of the vein above with your thumb, and insert the incident phlebotomy below, and make the vein rise above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you did in the two veins others: and make it run from the blood according to the amount of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then dissolve the weakness of the arm, and put your thumb on the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterward place over the same belly and thighs, and draw it up tightly from below with a strong constriction, and let it go until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And it has already been remembered here of their cutting and extraction in the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Regarding venial bleeding after the cephalic vein bleeding.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The operation of venial bleeding on the face comes after the cephalic vein bleeding, to old diseases of the face: and to hemorrhoids, and redness: and a grievous ulcer.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this bleeding is, according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The weak neck of his collar with a knife, until it becomes visible.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called the Fossil.
Cuius haec est forma.	And this is its form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point which is on the head of the Fossil above the venial bleeding, and press on it with your finger or with another in the same way: and let the blood run according to the amount you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the weak perforation, and draw it tight, until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it opens with the knife wide.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it should not be a sharp-pointed knife like the others, but rather a wide-bladed one.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the bleeding of it according to transuasion: because the mouth is near: and perhaps in it the knife breaks when it is thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Regarding venial bleeding in the two lacrimal veins.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The operation of the two veins which are in the two lacrimal veins of the two eyes is to the eye from scabs and redness: and it is in the eye, and old diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	The quality of their phlebotomy is such that it draws the weak neck of its own body with a pinprick.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then perform the phlebotomy: and you will be standing over its head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebotomy be made according to the transfusion to a short distance, when the phlebotomy is small, wide, because there is no flesh.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If indeed the phlebotomy is a thin extremity, it may be broken.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make the blood flow as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a bandage over them, and tie them up at night once, and dissolve them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	¶ About the phlebotomy of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	However, the phlebotomy of the nose is to be performed for acute fever, and severe thirst, and facial diseases such as hemiplegia and redness that occurs on the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is such that it draws the weak neck of its own body.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold the nose of its left hand with yours, and take a thin and long phlebotomy, and tie it in the middle of the rabbit's, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the nose does not appear to the sense, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary to use your last hand with a small phlebotomy: and make the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then tie it up at night once.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it restores quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	¶ About the phlebotomy of the nose of Guidegi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	However, the phlebotomy of the two Guidegi noses is to be used for constriction of thirst, and the onset of leprosy, and melancholic diseases, and impetigo and ulcers bad, and corroding, that is, herpes is.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	The quality of the phlebotomy is such that it draws out the weak from both sides of their neck with the tie: and the artificer stands over the head of the weak, and the weak sits over his own seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then, a second phlebotomy is made along the length of the phlebitis.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then, remove an equal amount of tempered blood from the blood, or according to what you see is necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then, do the same with another phlebotomy.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards, loosen the tie, and tighten the two bandages in the middle: so that the weak is not prioritized.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And release it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	It will be healed, for the wound.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	¶ About the phlebotomy of Algebra.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	However, the veins of Algebra have a phlebitis because they nourish alcohol in the mouth, and corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers: and fissures of the lips, and bad ulcers, even those that are in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebitis is such that you make the weak sit before you, and tighten the neck of his collar with a rope.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then, roll over the lip of the weak, and look at the two bandages: one is from his right lip, and the other from his left: and the demonstration of both is by blackening of the gums.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true, because there are small and black veins around it.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore, make an incision on both incisions.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	However, if you have any doubt about it, and you do not know what it is: then consider the larger incision of its own, and the most obvious one.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	Similarly, do the same for the two teeth that are above the lip: and above all, custom runs towards this: and cut two teeth that are below the lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Regarding phlebotomy of the vein beneath the tongue, after the cephalic vein phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	However, the phlebotomy of the two veins beneath the tongue is, that the phlebotomy of the cephalic vein is for the prevention of affections which are in the throat, and of the uvula, and affections of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is, that it should be seated between your hands in the sun: and the eyelid thereof, and look under the tongue from the side of one eye, and from the side of the other eye: and the color of both should incline to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore, the phlebotomy of both: and take care not to use your hand too much in the phlebotomy of them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under these are arteries, and perhaps there may be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Regarding the three veins in the elbow:
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	However, the three veins that are phlebotomized in the elbow are those whose phlebotomy has run through all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their phlebotomy is made in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pressing with the phlebotomy myrtle wide, or olive oil to the thinness: or by drying with the phlebotomy cloth, and it is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is the form of it.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, which is convenient for the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these are species of the flat ones, and the thin ones according to the broadness of the tongue and the stricture of them: the form of the phlebotomy myrtle is flat, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	It comes to the opening of fenestras (windows), full, flowing, apparent, heavy, and those that contain much blood, turbid.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy is of smaller latitude, and more delicate at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it comes to the phlebotomy of the thin veins that contain thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	¶ About the phlebotomy of the Basilican vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, the Basilican vein is one of the three veins' phlebotomy jewels.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from afflictions that are under the throat and neck, because it follows the chest, and the vein: and it comes to the phlebotomer with the phlebotomy of that one, so as to avoid it, and let it be over fear of it, for there is an artery under it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If then he errs, and adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will incise that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary, not to phlebotomize her with a sharp phlebotomy: in fact, she should be cutting with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	That if the Basilican apparition is not manifest, then it is necessary to change the vein itself, or to turn it to another, or to ask for a branch of that one: or to phlebotomize in the place of that one's Funem brachii.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is manifest, and you should dry it with Alnesil, as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If then you wish to phlebotomize that of the same one, then it is necessary before the tightening of the Funem brachii, to touch the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then, signs are placed on the spot with wax, then the arm, and a clean section with the cauterizing iron of Al-Nasir, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And so that it does not fall by the impact through the space from the artery's place.
