Then command the two attendants to hold one of them who is above the fracture with his hands, and for the other to hold the lower part of it, and extend each of them to their own part.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you wish for the extension to be stronger, then tie under the fracture with a ligament, and above it with another ligament: and extend them each of the two attendants to their own parts.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If then the fracture is near the end of the arm, then it is necessary that one ligament be laid under the elbow, and the other under the fracture turned towards the thigh.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And similarly if the fracture is near the elbow, then it is necessary that a ligament be laid on that place and above the elbow itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then make the fracture equal and easy without effort until it is equal to the fracture according to what is appropriate, and apply a good application: then tie it, if there is no heat from the post.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	If however, a heat from the post occurs, then release the tied one until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And put on top of it the wine-soaked wool that has been absorbed in vinegar and rose oil, until the heat from the post is quieted: then tie it: and the way to tie it is to put the plaster on top of the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then put the ointment made from a new cloth over the plaster.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then he brings together the arm over the aid and places his hand openly on his own shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And place the bandage, and tighten the arm over the aid so that the arm stands in the place of the stars: if nothing prevents you from that, neither will it bother you over anything broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	That is, if you fear that something will bother you over a broken bone, then use the stars: and it is good to place the larger and stronger star directly above the broken bone.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And place the stars between all the fingers: and the length of the stars should be according to the fracture with an addition of three digits from every part.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then tighten the bandage over the strings that I said at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And it is good that your bandage be tighter over the place of the fracture.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And as the fracture is elongated, so should the bandage be smaller.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If you then see the position and tightening of the stars as we said, in the hour when you restore the limb, then do so: and if you fear a hot splint, then release the bandage and the stars until the seventh day, as we said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then consider the ligament in all three days to see if there is no pruritus, inflammation, or a prohibition of food to the limb due to the excessive tightness of the bandage.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Therefore, correct this entire thing according to what we said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	But if you are over confident that nothing will happen from that: then do not untie the ligament unless after three days, or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	And let the back of his neck be weak and lie down on his chest, and place a full woolen bandage under the aid on his hand, equally.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	Consider the figure of the member at all times of the night or day, so that it does not break or soften the ligament.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	Correct that in its entirety with your skill.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And place the food for the weak in the order we have prescribed, so that the first food is fine and the mouth begins to tighten: then it is necessary to make the food of that member finer.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	For the habit of assistance and the thigh is, that it tightens in forty days: then it is necessary to make it loose, and a bath is given, and it is treated with ointments that strengthen that.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	If the fracture is a grievous one, let it be drawn out: then do not soften the ligament and the stars up to fifty days, and for two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	Regarding the restoration of the fracture of the Bragg's.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones, which are called the two foci.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	Of which one is small: and this is that which follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	And the other is large: and this is that which is placed below the small one from the lower part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Perhaps only the larger focus will break, or the smaller one: and perhaps both will break at once.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When the smaller focus above is broken, then the restoration of it is easy, and the healing of it is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the smaller focus below is broken, the fracture of it is bad, and its healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And it is worse when both bones are broken at once.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If the bone that is broken is the small one above, then the doctor is convenient at the restoration of it, to put a fine extension on it with ease, until it becomes its own.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	If indeed that great fire is what is broken, then it is necessary for him to put on a stronger, tighter bandage.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And it is necessary for him to place the figure of the hand at the restoration of his, and its extended above the pulse.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And the hand should be raised above all fingers: and the inferior joint of all fingers, or rather others; and the weak one sitting quadratus over itself, and the pulse near him, or in front of him, at a height, so that the weak one does not fall under the strain.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then he should extend the helper's arm from the lower part, or his own arm, or with a bandage.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And the helper should also extend above similarly.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the doctor should adjust the jaw until he can reduce it according to the better figure that he can.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	If indeed there are flaps in the fracture of bones, then you should dare to reduce all fragment in its place with your own virtue.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	If indeed there appears to be a separate flap, and it punctures the skin, and there is no hope for its restoration: then find over it, and remove it according to the mode that I have said in those which were mentioned before.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	If however the fracture is with the tendon, then I have already made to that particular capitulum, therefore take care of its treatment from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	If however a post-operative fever occurs at the beginning of your restoration, then line the bandage with the cloth made by rubbing oil rosato, and white wax, and it should be between the density and the subtility: and tie the bandage over it with a fine thread, until it is sated with the fever: then remove the wax, and put on the prepared plaster from the mortar with albumine oui.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then place stars, and let the star that is placed over the fracture be somewhat larger and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	You know that the number of stars Brachii is six in several arrangements: if the fracture is in one focus, or in two focuses at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then place your stricture over a stronger and more vigorous part of the fracture, and slightly more when the stricture is directed towards the superior or inferior parts of the fracture, or place a softer stricture of its kind, according to what was remembered at the beginning of this chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And the sheets that cover over the fracture should be soft and moist, not hard or sharp.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let the thread by which it is tied be from linen properly, a medium between the fine and coarse, as we have mentioned.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And consider the member and the ligament after a day.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If something happens that requires correction, such as itching that occurs in the member: then it is necessary to wet the member with hot water, until the itching subsides, and release the member that is not constricted, until it subsides, and then repeat the stricture.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the stricture has already been softened, and the bone is remote, and similar to this: then correct this entirely with your virtue, and consider again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if nourishment is forbidden to the member because of the excess of the stricture, then it is necessary to soften it slightly, and release it for a few days, until it runs to the food, and then tie it again.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	But if something does not happen to make them weak, as we have said, then it is not necessary to untie, unless after nineteen days or about this.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then the hand of the weak person is hung down to its neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And let the neck of its person be equal, and let it be guarded by its own virtue from unnatural movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	And make it sleep over its back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	And know that this fracture is healed in thirty days, or in thirty-two days, and perhaps it is healed in the twenty-eighth day.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	The whole of this is according to the dispositions of the complexions, and the dispositions of the virtues.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	§ About the healing of bone fractures.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIII.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	Know that bone fractures of the fingers and toes are rare.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And it does not happen to them except repeated abrasion.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When then the plantar fracture or abrasion happens, it is necessary that the weak hand lies across the quadratus: and the seat should be placed in front according to equality.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place the hand of its person over the extended one.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then the assistant extends the broken bone, and adjusts it according to the physician, until they are united by a good connection.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary that he puts on plaster and bandage, if not a hot abscess does not occur.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then place the plaster over according to the quantity of the wound: and you have already covered it in linen bandage.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	If however the fracture is to the lower part of the plant around the ventricle, then make a similar sphere from linen: and let the weak person lie across it with his broken foot: and then it should be tied with a long bandage.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let the plaster be of hide, in which there is softness, so that the skin applies to the body of the foot: and tie it according to what is necessary.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	If then the fracture is to the outer side, then it should be done thus: place a drop of oil on top, and another needle from below in the sole; and the hand should be extended straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then place the contracture as it rotates the hand: and extend between the fingers with the ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If then a fracture occurs at one of the joints of the fingers, then if it is the thumb, it should be done according to what is appropriate.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then tie with the sole: and if you love, place a straight needle on it, small: so that the fracture may be pulled out and not move.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	If then the fracture is in the other fingers such as the middle, index, or little finger, then it should be done thus: and it should be placed with a healthy digit that follows it: or they should all be tied according to the continuation: and it is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or place a small needle on top of the one we have already placed in the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider in your restoration, and after that placement, place hot stitches: and opposite when something happens from it according to the report of its story.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	¶ On the restoration of the hip bone fracture.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip bone is often broken and declared by touch: because it is turned to the inner and posterior part.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And the restoration of it is made in such a way that the ligament above the fracture is tied and another ligament below the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And it is made weak on its face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then extend all the ligaments that are ministers to their part according to equality: and this when the fracture is in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	If then the fracture is near the root of the hip bone, then it should be a ligament to the part of the tendon, so that the extension goes upwards: and another ligament below the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	If a near-fracture of the knee occurs, then the near-ligament of the knee should be extended towards the lower parts.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the physician should treat the bone of both hands until it is reduced according to the natural figure: and it should be united by a good connection.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary to place a plaster and bandage, if not an aposteme occurs in the member.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	If an aposteme occurs in that member: then let it be given some days to settle, until the hot aposteme is settled, and then return to your healing.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	However, this bandage should be such.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	It is necessary to tie above the hard fracture, that is, the binding: and tie it twice or three times: and let there remain some surplus.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then tie the thigh, until the heel of the calf is at the root of the nates.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	And insert a long string between the hip and thigh near the knee to the lower parts, and let the ends of the string be at the two parts from the upper part.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then roll over the thigh and hip that remains from the dough.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then place above the hip of the star that is in the place of the fracture of its own star, and place one star on the bone of the thigh.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill the voids between the thigh and hip with soft bands, so that the bandage is equal.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then begin with a strong bandage from the middle over the place of the fracture, three or four folds.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the more you elongate with the ligament from the place of the fracture, the less and softer your bandage should be, and softer.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then pay attention to the two ends of the string that you inserted between the hip and thigh.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Stitch therefore when it is either of the three stars that are above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then cut then with two extremities of the fillet to the lower parts, until the warts to the sole of the foot.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And if it binds also the other ends of the stars: so that the stitch does not come out of its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then loosen the stitch on that, while it remains, so that it does not happen to the member by corrosion, nor by gangrene, nor by inflammation, nor by such things.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	If something happens from that.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Therefore, if there is a remedy for this, and correct what happens from that, according to what we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	But if I say it is a fragment of bone that pains: then it is necessary to adjust it, if it is possible for you.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, find above that, and remove that: and take care with the one that precedes the reminder, until it is cured.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And when this fracture of the hip is stitched, besides the stars that we have said in aid and arm, so:
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However, in the restoration of it, when it is broken in that way, does not happen to a weak walk.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if it is restored alone, besides what is applied to the other leg, then it is necessary that he walks who has it, always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And you know that the hip is stitched in fifty days, or is added little, or decreased a little: all this is according to the diversity of the complexions, and the rest of the positions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	¶ About the restoration of the fracture of the knee-joint.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	You know that the knee-joint fracture rarely happens, but it happens to it often by attrition.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	If indeed a fracture occurs, then either a split or a hole is found in some of its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And this is when it is with the ulna, and without the ulna.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And he stands above it all with his senses.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And the restoration of it is such that it becomes equal to what was broken from its parts with the fingers, until it is gathered and connected according to what is possible from the equation and facility and craftsmanship.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then place the plaster made from wheat flour or milling with albumen if you need that: and place on top of it a round star, if you require that: and stretch it down conveniently for that.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the arrangements that we have mentioned in the other fractures, such as burned tendon, and like that: so that you place all accidents with what is convenient for it until it heals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	¶ Regarding the restoration of the thigh fracture.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	Know that the thigh is two bones, of which one is large and called the thigh, and the other small and called the focus.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And it happens that both kinds of fractures that happen to two bones of the arm, and therefore the restoration of it is like the restoration of the arm equally, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If they break two bones at once, the thigh is converted to all parts.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if it is broken more finely, the thigh is converted to the anterior part.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if it is broken more coarsely, you will find it lower: and it is from those that do not hide anything from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then apply the extension, and the equation, and the tying of the stars according to that equally.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	Indeed, if the fracture of the Thigh is a severe one, bearing many seths, then it should be a minor extension and a gentler alleviation of your own.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the Thigh indeed, there is something from the operation on the arm: and it is that when you make equal stars, and cover all your operation, then take two strips from pine wood, which is given in the making of solar panels that is placed under slabs: and they are made from palm leaves: and choose from them those which have a small grossness, and they should not be from the tiny ones: and their length should be according to the length of the Thigh from the knee downwards.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then cover over each strip with two folds according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And place one part of the Thigh on one side, and the other on the opposite side: and they should be from the knee down to the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then tie the two strips in three places at the two ends and the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	For when the tightening is forbidden, the Thigh leans to the right and left, and stands in a good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And already the cradle is made from wood according to the length of the Thigh, and it is placed in it with the Thigh, so that it may keep it from moving.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And especially it is necessary that you do this when the fracture is swollen properly.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then consider the Thigh every day, and study with it the last effort of the apostemate, or inflation, or other similar ones.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If then something happens from these, then apply it with what is appropriate, until it heals, if God wills.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	Of the bone fracture of the foot and toes.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	The heel itself does not undergo a complete fracture.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	The bones of the foot sometimes undergo a fracture, and even the fingers, but it does not occur except in grinding in various positions.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	If a fracture occurs in the bones of the foot, and you see the bone rise above itself to reach the prepared ground, as if walking, then he will place his weakened foot on the prepared ground.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then put your foot there, and place it on the thing that rises from those bones: then press or step on it: and the same one, until it returns to its place.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then place a plaster, and remove the bandage above: and place under the sole of the foot a small tablet with two flat caps.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then tie it with the foot tightly, after you have loosened it with the bands, and the rest that it needs.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	When they have been bound for three days, or four, then untie the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find the bone equal, if it is broken, or dislocated.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	The operation is therefore as you see.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	If however some fingers are broken, then restore them, and make them equal as I will tell you in the restoration of the fingers of the hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place your finger with the star according to the length of the finger, and make it a little larger than that: then place under the foot this tablet that I tell you, and tie it tightly.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	If however that which is broken from the bones is two, or three, or more, then place above all the fingers the star of its quantity, loosened in linen: and tie the tablet on the bottom of the foot: and let it stand on one cap of the tablet outside the sole of the foot, so that it holds good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	It happens to you that you do not overlook, but consider all that I have said to you about the remaining fractures from the accidents we have mentioned: and place every accident against what should be done.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	¶ Of the fracture of a woman's thigh bone, and of the bones of the fingers, and of women.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When a woman's thigh bone is broken, then make her sit square.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then lean her towards the back part of her own neck, and hold her back.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then the midwife should fill up the fracture of the woman's thigh bone with her own glove, until it is filled up, and let it be as round as a sphere.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then she should be made to shake, and gradually raise the back of her own body.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	This cot will exit, until it is round before the thigh bone of the woman, and the broken bone returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then place a pillow under her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When she wishes to move, remove the cot with ease, then let her move: and then reduce it according to the way you introduced it at first: then return it to the pillow of her own first.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Let her do this for seven days, or about, for the bone will be restored.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you will, take a vesical, and tie it over the hole of her bone, and introduce the whole vesical into her thigh bone.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the vesical with all your might, until the vesical is let out within the thigh bone, for the fracture returns.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then fill it up with the cot, and stand for some days, according to what we have mentioned, until she is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the finger bone is broken, then administer in the restoration of it, and the proportion which we have mentioned in the bone of Ancha.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	The correct path is not hidden in these nearby fractures, which are rare, especially in those who have some knowledge or experience of the subject.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	Understand my book thoroughly, for the fracture itself indicates to you in many positions a correct path in the restoration of his own and the tightening of his: therefore understand.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	When the virga (rod) of the man is broken, take the guts (intestines) of a goose: and insert the woman (vagina) into herself.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place it on the same fold of cloth, and it will be bound and left for three days, or about that time, and it will be healed if God wills.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	¶ Regarding the restoration of a bone fracture when it is with a tendon.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	If it suits him who has a bone fracture with a tendon, especially if it is large, such as the hip bone, or an aid, or similar to it, so that it can be done quickly, and you are told the conditions for phlebotomy, as we have said.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	If the tendon lets out blood, then it is necessary that you go quickly to the abscess of it, so that you grind over it with a sharp knife: if there is no other present to you.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to restore the fracture in that same day: and do not postpone it if it does not happen to be a relapse.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	If I say, a hot relapse happens, then let the restoration of it be until the ninth day, until the relapse is settled.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach him on the third and fourth days, for you are making bad things happen to him.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	If the broken bone is prominent above the detected skin: then it is necessary that you try to reduce it and make it equal with your hands, with ease and extension small.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If however not prepare its extension, and its own equality with your hands: then reduce it with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And this is the instrument made of iron, whose length is equal to seven digits or eight, and its width is according to the size of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And therefore it is necessary for the physician to take from them three or four according to the quantity he needs for the treatment of all kinds of fractures.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And it should be rounded: and there should be a small thickness in it, so that it does not double on top of itself during compression at the hour of the operation: and its sharp ends should have a margin at its sharp ends.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And it should be above it according to its thickness from the middle to its lower parts.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	In this operation it is necessary to place the sharp, rough end of its extremity over the prominent end of the bone: and push it with that hand until the bone returns and equals a certain equality.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	Therefore, let us try to equalize the ends of the fracture that are coming out.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	If however the ends of its fracture are fine and it does not take it with good reception of the instrument, then let it try to injure the end of that bone, until the instrument has power over it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	If however you cannot reduce them with the one we have mentioned, then injure it with the one we have mentioned, or cut it with any kind of knife possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then polish that which remains in the bone from its roughness and minute bark.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When the bone is reduced and it finds a weak painful one after its reduction, then you know that the bone has not returned to its natural place.
Fac ergo illud.	Therefore, do this.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	However, you are giving me a large impediment when your restoration is complete and you make the bone.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then immerse the cloth in a black, alcoholic solution.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And especially if it is in summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place on the back a poultice of turf or anything containing oil: so as not to cause putrefaction and corruption in the same place.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then apply stars in the hour of your complete restoration of the bone.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And let the back be detected: so that you may strike with needles at the wounds according to the number of the wounds.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And be careful not to bind the back with a fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	Indeed, many doctors have done this foolishly: and they have caused death, or putrefaction, or corruption, or scarring on healthy ones.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And your stricture be gentle, soft, and varied in the remaining fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	If the back is bad, or is a large back, and you fear some bad things that we have mentioned above, and you find pain in the place hanging: then it will not be necessary to put stars on it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make these incisions from hard cloths in the place of the stars, and bind them together with it.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	But when it has been one day or two days, and you see the back beginning to come out, so that a pus is generated in it: then take off the cloth which you have put on above the back with alcohol.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply a bandage, and ointment with which we are accustomed to heal wounds: such as the Tetrapharmacon ointment, and like it.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	It agrees with you, so you dissolve the ligament.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And examine the wound every day in the morning and evening until it heals and becomes sound.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it is necessary to prepare the member in such a way that pus flows from it to the lower parts with ease.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If many days pass without the wound healing and the pus does not discharge from it, then you know that there are small bones broken in that place.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Because it is necessary to examine the wound when it is touched.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of them are separated and removed, remove them and take them out.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And which of them are not separated and pierce the member, and cause pain to happen, may be pricked and removed in any way that is possible for you to do that.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If the wound is inflamed, or suppurating, that is, if it has a feverish or putrid appearance, then it is necessary to oppose one of them with the other that agrees with the cure of the member whose case is related in the chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And in the one in which it is necessary for me to say this, and with whom you make your present mind when the bone breaks and goes over the member, as the hipbone, and the thigh, and similar ones in other large members, it does not happen often that it attracts them, because death often happens from that, even let it be, until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps it may fall by itself in ninety days, or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then take care of the wound if you see it: and if not, let it be.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	¶ About the treatment of the nodification in the fracture of a bone.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	This happens often in the way of this nodation in the path of healing of fractures.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially, which is near the joints: and becomes deformed in its figure from this.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps it may prevent the member from its natural operation.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Consider then, if the nodation is recent: administer to it medicines which have an styptic property, such as aloe, and olibanum, and myrrh, and sarcocolla, and acacia, and such like.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Thus, take some of these, or all of them: and confuse them with vinegar, or with albumen, or with acid: and place them over the nodation in the wound, and bind them firmly over the same stricture good.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And release the stricture, nor dissolve it in many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then dissolve it, and use another, until the nodation be removed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or bind it over the same lead plate.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	For lead has the property to remove everything which is feared from the members.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the nodation is already turned to the stone, and is strict, and a sudden necessity is required to remove it: then find over it from its upper part, and cut off the superfluous part: or grate it with some sharp instruments, until it be removed: and take care of it until it be healed.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	¶ When it is healed, and the member remains sound after that, it does not happen according to its nature.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When the fracture of the bones is healed, and the member remains sound after that weak, it does not happen except for many causes.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	Of which one is, the multitude of the solutions and ligations of it not according to what ought to be: or because of the superfluity of the stricture of the ligaments, until it be prohibited the food to run to the member: or because of the superfluous embrocation in its unsuitable time: or because of the smallness of blood in the body of the weak, and its weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	The treatment for this condition is to feed it with weak and tender food, until blood is multiplied in it.
Et administra balneum.	And apply a bath to it.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and merry company to him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then place a plaster over the member: so that it may attract the plaster to the food in large amounts.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And apply ointment to it with hot water, until the food flows out and returns to its natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	¶ About the curing of broken bones when they twist.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When the member has already been restored after the healing of the bone and the fracture or nodation, and it becomes deformed due to the broken bone: and it is deformed in its shape, but the member is not prevented from performing its natural operation: then it does not need to accept the speech of him who thinks that the bone should be broken again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there have been many stupid doctors and restorers who have done this on our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And this operation is indeed shameful, leading to death or great fear, so that it may be deadly.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the claudication and nodation are recent: then it should be applied with hot water, in which decoctions of softening herbs have been added, such as the leaves of the high-growing plant, and its root, and melilot, and similar ones.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And make for it a plaster with softening plaster, such as dyachilon made appropriately.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or consider the mucilage of the high-growing plant, and mix it with chicken fat, or with olive oil: and apply it with that.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or use ripe figs, and bind them with fine linen, and similar ones that are named from decreasing medicines to strengthen the consolidation.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	When the knot is untied with constant, old, and gentle friction made with wet hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And the motion of the limbs is given to every part in all hours.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	If however, the knot has already become twisted, and has been made strong, and has struck against the stone, and has called for attention to its care with iron: then it should be cut off as above, and the continuity of bones should be released, and the excess from the knot or bone with the sharp knives should be cut off: and ease should be given in that place with anxiety and diligence.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	Regarding speech in Dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the exit of some joint from its place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Because it is forbidden from its own motion, and its figure becomes deformed.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it causes severe pain and grievous wounds to come upon the weakest.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When then a dislocation occurs in someone, it is necessary to hurry to the restoration of that one: and there should be no delay at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it delays, the place will become postponed, and perhaps with it the restoration of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore, it does not need to move, nor extend in the hour of its postponement.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For it often causes a spasm and painful wounds.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when that happens, it is necessary to hurry to the bleeding of the weak one.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then it is released, until the postponement has rested.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb is rubbed with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it is returned with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And all the limbs are cared for with that one whose memory fails in its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have already arranged the chapter of dislocation, even according to what precedes in the fracture, from the upper part of the body down to its lower part.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	Regarding the care of the dislocation of the lower jaw.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The lower jaw is rarely dislocated except in two cases.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	The dislocation of the lower jaw occurs according to one of two methods.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are removed from their places by a slight removal and are softened somewhat.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated in a complete and integral manner, until they are softened to the chest, until the weak jaw is curved, and it cannot hold it, nor close its mouth, and the tongue of its speaker is uncovered.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	However, when the dislocation of it is small, it returns to many positions by itself with little quantity.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If however the dislocation is complete and integral, then it should be that the reduction of it is made quickly and not delayed: and it is necessary that it holds firmly the weak head: and the physician inserts his thumb of one hand into the root of the dislocated jaw between the teeth of it, if the dislocation is from one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he inserts both of his hands at once, if the dislocation is from two sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the rest of his fingers are outside, by which he can equal it.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And he commands the weak one to clean his jaws and to free them for eating to all parts.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician can hold the jaw and push it, until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If however the reduction is difficult, especially if both jaws are at once: then he should make a ointment with hot water and oil, until a easy reduction of it is made to the lower jaw: and he does not delay the reduction of it altogether, as we said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they finally fall asleep and close their wounds, and are not softened: then place some flax cloths over them, with a piece of wax that has been made from wax: and rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then a bandage is applied with ease, using soft ligatures.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And the sleep of the weak should be on their back: and the head of it should stand between two flax cloths, so that it does not move to the right and left: nor is it compelled, or forced to chew anything: indeed, a food of its own desire is placed under its jaw, until when the pains subside, and the mandible is sutured: then it eats what it wants, and it is administered with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	It does not labor over the operation of its own mouth at eating and drinking, and the nodding, until the mandible is sutured, and it is healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If it is difficult to reduce the two mandibles when they are dislocated at some time and do not return to their places: then many fevers occur from there, and constant diet: and perhaps the weak belly is loosened, and perhaps the bitter purification of choler is vomited.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see that: then you know that it is a loss, and many die that are affected by this in ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	¶ About the reduction of the shoulder joint dislocation, and the extremity of the humerus.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The shoulder joint, however, is not dislocated from the inner side, because of its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it is sometimes dislocated to the outside: and this is declared by touch.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And the restoration of it is, that it lies weak on its back, and extends its arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then place it in a strong position with your palm, because it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place the plaster over the same, and the bandages, and tie it tightly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities of these, which follow the thigh, and continue with it, are not easily dislocated, except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is dislocated on any day: then it must be reduced and made equal as we have said, and prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place the plaster over the same, the bandages, and the tied one.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And instruct the surgeon to remain calm and quiet until it heals.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when this same treatment is applied to the extremity of the shoulder, when it separates even from its own place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	¶ About the reduction of the shoulder dislocation.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You know that the shoulder is not dislocated unless in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of which is, that it be dislocated to the side of the titillation towards the lower part.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is, that it be dislocated to the side of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated to the upper part of the shoulder: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it is not dislocated to the back, because of the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated to the front, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And it is most often dislocated and goes out to the lower part, turning away from the titillation: especially in those, where the flesh is few.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	For it goes out quickly in them, and comes quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those where the flesh is many, it is opposite to that, for it comes out with difficulty, and goes in with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens in some men by blow or accident, and the shoulder is struck with hot iron, and it is thought that it is dislocated because of that.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	It is therefore necessary to try this, until you are certain of it, and then proceed to treat it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And the dislocation is known when the shoulder is turned towards the chest: and you distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a sound one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you find a clear difference between them, and you find a union in the head of the humerus, and under the titillation at the touch of the head of the humerus as if it were one bone: and an infirm person cannot make the hand move to their own ear, nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if the shoulder is dislocated towards the chest or upwards: you will find a clear touch, and it does not hide.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And this dislocation is easy to reduce when it is recent or the child is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	The reduction of this is that he should raise his own hand to the upper part.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your hands under the titillation of this, and raise the joint with strength to the upper part of its own place: and he should raise his hand and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then he will lower it down, for he returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	But if he does not return by what I have said, and the days that pass before it happens are many: then it is necessary to bathe the weak person in hot water, and apply an ointment that softens and soothes, as if the roots of the tall grasses, and the grapevine, and the mallow were rubbed in and put in the water, and applied.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the weak person will rise on his back: and a sphere and wool that is equal between softness and rigidity is placed under the titillation of this.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician will place his heel on the sphere, and raise the head of the humerus with strength, and draw the weak hand downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	Another attendant should hold the head of the weak one, so that it does not move to the lower parts: for he himself returns immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	If you wish, place him according to this manner: and let the present man be longer for the weak one, and stand on the side of the side, and insert his arm under the weakened shoulder: and lift the weakened shoulder upwards until it is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	Another attendant should draw the weak hand towards the lower ventricle of him.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If the weak one is lying on his back: then it is necessary that something else be hung from him, so that it weighs him down, because the dislocation returns immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	It is also reduced according to another manner: and it is that the log, whose head is round figure like the handle of a mortar, should be laid on the ground: that is not heavy, nor light.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then the cloths are laid on the weak one after the logs have been placed on his head: and the weak one should stand according to the length of the log.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then the hand of him is extended towards the lower part of the other side, and his body is extended from the other side with strength: because the joint returns to its place with weakness.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If it is difficult to reduce him by all that I have said: then use this care: and it is that you take a log whose length is the quantity of two arms, and whose width is the quantity of four fingers, and whose thickness is the quantity of two fingers: whose head is round, so that the entrance of his shoulder goes into it deep, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then the soft cloths are tied over the round head: so that they do not hurt the weak one.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then the weak one is laid on the weakened shoulder, so that the hand or arm extends over the log up to the lower parts: and the log is placed over the helper, the arm, and the end of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then the arm is laid over the step of the ladder across its width, and the hand is extended to the lower part, and the rest of the body is let down from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The joint immediately enters.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When the opening is completed as much as possible: then it is necessary to place under a flat sphere of equal quantity from wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place the prepared plaster made from flour with olibanum and almond glue over the entire arm as it rotates.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tie the appropriate bandage: and let the rope rotate over the plaster: and connect the hand of this to the neck of its own, and let it hang, and do not allow the hand of this to move for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary to place soft food, until the limb is strengthened, because it is more beneficial for its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then a larger one is placed after seven days, or five, and it is moved with motion.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If it holds firm and is not softened, then it is already cured.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If the joint is dislocated many times, due to the moisture that happens to it, or for some other cause: then it is necessary to apply this cauterant with three holes, according to what was said in the chapter of cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If this is all done and the ligament is loosened after seven days, and the joint is not strengthened, and the plaster and bandage are applied again to it several times, and it does not hold, and it falls, and cannot be lifted up to the shoulder: then you know that the bones of its arm which are towards the head of the humerus are already cut, or stretched, or softened: and you know that the joint is never set in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	Dislocations, however, are caused by the force of pulling and extending the chest and breast, and they are reduced with impulse when it returns, and the remaining tightness and care are given until it is cured.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If, however, it occurs after cure and there is stiffness in the member and slowness in its movement, then a weak bath should be used many times until the stiffness is relieved and it returns to its original state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	¶ Treatment of the Dislocation of the Knee.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	You know that the dislocation of the knee joint is difficult, and it also returns with difficulty, especially to all parts, and particularly to the front and back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you: for it is falling under the use, and under the touch, according to whichever figure it is dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you reduce the dislocated knee with the sound one, it is clearly shown to you.
