Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	The joint is concealed, and it cannot double the arm, nor touch with its own elbow.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to hurry and reduce the dislocation immediately before it becomes a hot sprain.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if a hot sprain occurs to it, the reduction becomes difficult: and perhaps it is not cured at all, especially when it is to the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	For it is worse in every kind of dislocation and more violent pain: and often it dies with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the restoration of it is when it can be reduced by those that are possible to be reduced, and the hand of the patient is extended with two hands: and the arm of the patient is expanded, and the hand of the physician is above the knee and under it, and he presses the dislocation with his palms of his hands simultaneously, or with the root of his thumb, until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	If indeed it is a dislocation to the front, then it returns thusly, so that the hand doubles with its own hand, until it strikes with the root of its palm, which is dislocated, with its own little finger.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the dislocation does not yield to reduction, then administer a strong extension, with firm hold: and it is, as if two hands were extending the arm, and both hold it, so that it does not move during extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is turned over to all parts, after it has been reduced above the palm of the hand, whether it be a long doubled bandage or a wide ligament.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when it touches the physician's hand with the joint, anoint it with oil: so that it be one of those which aid in the lubricity of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then he will drive the joint with a strong push, until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after the reduction of it, it is necessary that it be laid on the same plaster, wherein there is stipticity, and exudation with the bone: and it should be tied in a proper manner.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And hang the arm from the weak neck: and let it remain for some days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it is unfastened.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If then the joint is firm in its place, then unfasten the ligament from it, and let it go.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see the joint not to be well tied, then repeat the plaster, and the ligament, and let it go for some days, until it is tied.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then let it go.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If however, oldness comes to it after the reduction of the joint, and it is in motion: then administer hydration in the bath, and subtle friction, and compression, until it becomes tight, or lay it on the same joint, that is, the fat nates of a pig.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then, let it lie and release her on that day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then, take it away and insert him into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When he is washing, then scrape the joined part with gentle rubbing.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then, dip it over her again once, and twice, and a third time with the introduction of the bath, until it becomes soft.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you wish, place over her feces a damp, heated wax, and twist it over her.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	She becomes softened, and returns to its original position.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	¶ About the treatment of dislocations in Almahassem.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The hand of Mahassem is often dislocated, that is, the joint between the arm and the hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of this dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	The contrary of the others is jointed.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that there be ease in the reduction of this dislocation at the time of its dislocation, before the place be seized; or it may happen in the seizure of the place a hot aposteme.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of this dislocation is that you place Mahassem's weak hand over the table, and extend her other hand; and the physician places his palm over the prominence of the joint, and presses it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that it be considered if the palm has already receded to the vent of the hand: then he places his weak back over the table at the extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is proceeding to the back of the hand, then the position of his hand intrinsically over the table is that the inner part of his hand is placed over the prominence of the joint, so that the hand of the physician falls on its own prominence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If he returns immediately, it is good: and if not, then grasp it with ointment while it is seated, and let him go, without troubling about this.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if he does not endure, nor can you supervise his reduction after he has left him for several days, nevertheless the union remains according to the texture of his own nature: and it will not hurt the weak at all, unless his hand is softened, and he cannot hold anything: then you know that the nerves are either ruptured or merely scratched.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	It is not genius in this, unless it is held with ointment near the risk of its case.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps it does not harm anything.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When Almahassem does not return, then place the ointment we have mentioned over him.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then it is grasped and let go for five days, and then it is loosened and let go, and the hand is exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If however, the movement of his body is arrested, and something heavy happens to it within it: then ease it with warm water and friction several times, until it is eased.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	¶ About the treatment of the dislocation of the digits.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a digit is dislocated from any of them, or from the back of the palm, or from its ventrum: then extend the finger, and press the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger and suspend the reversed part to which it is dislocated for two days, and let it go.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it and extend it until it is straight in that day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When it is night, tie it according to the description: and do not cease to untie it in the day: and exercise it with motion: and tie it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	This should be done after some days, until it is tightened.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	Similarly, if it is dislocated to the belly of the hand, and you have done the first part of your operation, tighten it to its own part, and then do the operation again until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	Similarly, when it is dislocated to other parts, do the operation as before.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	¶ On the treatment of a dislocation of the Dorsospine.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to anyone that the Dorsospine is dislocated, or the complete dislocation of the neck, or the Spondiles are pulled out from their places: then there is no cure in this case, because death comes to the weak.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of this is that the weak one goes out without will, and cannot hold it, and often some members of him are softened, or two thighs of him, or two arms of his, or one of them: or the Spondile is pulled out from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For it is often removed because it is often made to be removed to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Therefore, that which is removed to the back, is called Gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The cure of it is, that you consider this now, if Gibbosity happens from childhood: then there is no cure in this case, neither is there any healing at all.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But in the other that happens by chance, or by hitting, or similar to these, the ancients have already spoken about the modes of curing with a long speech.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Whose most does not return when beneficial.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have already briefly spoken of it, which does not excuse much from much proximity to my house: and from my explanation, in which I explained that, and shaped the instrument of it in a different way from what they showed it, and explained it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I declare that there is no intelligence or cure from the gangrene that occurs from the anterior part.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly, in those that occur to both sides as well.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not cured from them, unless those that happen in the back properly, as I say: and it is, as it extends over its face above the heel, nearly up to the wall: and it is expanded under it with a moist string, so as not to hurt the chest of its.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight log is placed on the ground, fixed in the heel at the end of the foot, nearly at the head of its: and another log is placed at the other end of its foot: and it should hold the log, and it should not be firmly fixed in the heel.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And it should hold the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then cover over the weak head, and under the ligament of its gently, tightly: and extend the end of the ligament to the log that is at its head: and tie it up in it.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then stretch another string above the ankles of its, and above its knees, and at its heels.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the strings together, and tie them up in the other log that is at its feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then the holder will extend all the strings to the part of the log ligament, and the two logs should not be removed from their places where they are fixed: but they should not be firmly fixed, as I said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician will put his hands on the spine with strength, until he returns: or he will put it over a table.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he will tie his feet to the table until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If however he does not return by this treatment, then take the table whose length is about three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	The surgical incision should be made on the wall near the weakest point, where the table's edge enters.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the table on the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	The physician should then place his feet on the opposite end of the table.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	The physician should tie it tightly until the spine is compressed and return to his place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then, if you wish, operate with the hand that is wrapped around your arm: and it is as if you are placing two sticks on the ground near the weakest part of the foot, where the length of one brachium is equal to the length of the other.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And the length of the stick between all the fingers of your hand should be equal to one palm: and already there is a hole in every place where the tornum runs: and it should be firmly planted on the ground a lot, so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And then he inserts the round stick: and the tornum is where the ligament rotates in two holes of two sticks.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at the end of it there is a hole where the stick is firmly planted, whose length is equal to the hand that rotates it, and in two other sticks it is also like this.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tie the ligaments that you have tied in the weak chest of the tornum that is at the head of it: and tie the ligaments that you have tied in the legs of it in the tornum that is at the foot of it.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then stand at all the minor tornums that rotate the hand of your leg with the ligament, and the physician should compress the spine according to what we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the tornum that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then after the spine is compressed and returns to its place, then it is necessary to put the plaster of ichor with albumin on the wound.
Deinde stuppam.	Then he applied a dressing.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a star-shaped piece from the tablet, whose width is three digits, or about them.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And the length of it should be such that it occupies the place of Gibbositatis, and above a part of Sanae's spine.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is placed with the bandage that we mentioned.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And a weak nourishment of fine substance is used until it heals.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If there remains some prominence in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary that the medicines which soften and ease be given, with the administration of the tablet that we mentioned at a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And already the lead is being administered in that layer.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes there is a prominence in the end of the spine of the back: and it is supposed to be a dislocation, and that is the bone that has already projecting.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it does not belong to be presumed to it with this medicine, perhaps it will cause death to happen.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	¶ About the treatment of Anchae's dislocation.
Caput XXXII.	Caput XXXII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You know that the joints of Anchae and the joints of the elbow do not happen unless it is a dislocation only: nor does it happen to them which happens to other joints by removal small and conduction.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed the joint of Anchae is dislocated according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	For what reason it is that it is dislocated to the front and back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And indeed it is mostly dislocated to the inside: and very little to the front and back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment of the dislocation of it to the inside is: because when you join the weak thigh with a sound one with a weak one, it is longer: and the thigh of his is more prominent than the sound one, and the weak one cannot extend its foot at the inguinal area: and it is the place which follows the inguinal area struck by fire, because the head of the hip has already been soaked there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	The mark of this is that a dislocation occurs on its outside, which are its opposite circumstances.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	The mark of this is that a dislocation occurs in the front, because it extends the sound thigh according to the complement: indeed it does not double itself without pain which is in the knee: and if it strives to walk, it cannot go over that in front: and it retains its urine, and it is pinched at its buttock, and there is a cushioning of its thigh at its heel during walking.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	The mark of this is that a dislocation occurs in the back, as it does not extend the thigh, nor can it double itself before doubling the knee: and its thigh is also shorter on the other side: and the buttock is softened, and the head of the hip is at that place.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	Reduction, however, of this dislocation is that you should consider at that time, if the dislocation is habitual, which is already old with having it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then, if you perform a reduction of it, and it remains according to its disposition: then there is no cure at all in it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore, it does not follow that there should be a presumption of great pain.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	In that one whose dislocation is recent, and it is of one of the four kinds of dislocations: then promptly to this, if you want to join it, extend it to the interior and to the exterior, and move it right and left: perhaps it will return, and there will be no need for another care.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If, however, it does not return in this way, then it is necessary to prepare a strong attendant, and extend the thigh of its lower part: or with its hands, or with the bandage that is laid on its thigh above the knee: and another attendant extends its hand over the fingers of its, so that it pushes its own hand under the fingers of its.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then he ties it with a gentle bandage over the root of the hip bone, and holds onto the other end of the ligament.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And its extension should be from the front of the thigh to the shoulder or from the back to the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And their extensions should be of equal length until the weak one hangs down with his body from the earth and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	For this is the common form of the four kinds of extensions.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If then the displacement returns with that which I said, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary for every kind of this that I will say about its treatment.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In the reduction itself of that kind, when the displacement is to the inside, it is necessary for the weak one to be hung over the sound side of its own.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then he will put the bandage over the root of the hip bone, in the part that is between the head of the hip bone and the place under the thigh.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then he will extend the bandage upwards from the front of the thigh to a higher part of the body, to the shoulder.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then he will take another strong arm for him, and will reduce the large part of the weak thigh, and will extend it to a strong extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	And now it returns to its own place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	For this is the easiest of the other kinds of treatment for this member.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If however, he is excused from you and does not obey you to enter with this kind of treatment altogether: then it is necessary for two weak feet to be tied together with a strong and gentle bandage over two calcanei, and over two knees; and the length of each should be of the same size as the four digits of its own quantity: and the weak one should be extended more by the quantity of two digits.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then the weak one is hung up on the head of the wooden beam, which is at home: and its length is equal to the quantity of two forearms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then have the strong man of the youth press the head of the thigh: and let it hang with the weak one at another place: and let the strong man of the youth push the thigh with strength, for the joint returns to its place with weakness.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	In the reduction of its own joint, when it is dislocated to the outside, it is necessary that the weak one lies on the foot, according to what we have said about the genuine deformity.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And the tendon is tied above the thigh of the weak one, properly, and above his breast.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two beams are placed, one at his foot, and another at the head of the same.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a beam is placed in the middle of the thigh, fixed well: over which wet bandages are placed so that it does not hurt the weak one: and the beam should be between the thighs so that it does not attract to the lower parts during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all the helpers extend to their own part, and the physician ensures the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If then he obeys to the reduction, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place over the same tablet, and press it equally as we have said in the deformity, on the same.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, it is necessary that the weak one lies on his own sound side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it is necessary that the weak thigh is stretched out carelessly: and this is according to the same statement over the thigh: and the physician places his right hand palm on the weak groin.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he bends it with his other hand, and places it extended to the lower part of the same leg.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	If the dislocation is to the back: then it is not necessary for the weak one to extend to the lower parts, and to be raised above the ground: rather, it should be placed above a hard object, just as it is necessary when it is also dislocated wide on the outside, according to what we said about his pillow over two bellies: it is above his face, and the ligaments are extended: according to what we said earlier.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it should be given compression with the table, even above the place to which it is going to be rejoined, when the reduction is complete according to what is necessary.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of the reduction will not be hidden from you: and it is that the weak ones extend two legs: and when you see them equal, and the weak one strings his own leg, and expands it without excuse: then you know that the member has already returned, according to what is necessary: then join the two thighs, and put on plaster, and tie with a tight rope, so that it does not move widely to any part: and the weak one should hold tight for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then untie the ligament, and the plaster, and compare the leg with the other: then if you see them equal in state, then you know that the dislocation is already firm: therefore, the weak one should be able to walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see something of softening: then return, and the plaster of that, and tie it according to your first tightness: and let it be loose for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then untie that and make it slow in walking over the other for a few days until it is well recovered.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	¶ About the dislocation of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	¶ Chapter XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	The dislocation occurs on the outside, inside, and bottom, that is, to the back.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it is not dislocated to the front.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	The sign of this dislocation is that it is bent downwards, as if to apply its thigh to its own hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	However, if it does not adhere to the hip: then you know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	The restoration of all modes of this dislocation is to make the weak one sit upright, so that it may extend its thigh as far as possible, and your back may be against its face if it can, and place its foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then make it cling to the knee of your hand, and make the fingers of your hand straight above the knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your hand's palm the two sides of the knee with strength.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another extends its foot, until it returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	The sign of return is that it clings to the thigh with the hip in ease, not laboriously.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply the plaster itself, and make it cling to the thigh with the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind it together for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	Then untie it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And the weak one should not use walking for a few days until it is cured.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	However, if it refuses your reduction, then administer a strong extension with the ligaments that precede the story of Anchaea, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	¶ Treatment of Dislocation of the Heel (Calcaneus)
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The heel is sometimes reduced by a small removal, and sometimes it is dislocated according to the complement.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation is made, either to the inside or outside.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	The sign of this dislocation is that you see the calcaneus swollen, proceeding to the part to which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment of this displacement is a easy reduction: and it is that it extends with ease with the hands, and becomes equal, until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the treatment of this however when it is dislocated according to the complement, it is necessary that you make the weak one sit upright: and hold it with a strong assistant from the posterior part of the back of it, in the middle of itself.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold it with your right hand leg of it from the upper part of it, and with your left hand from the lower part of the foot of it in the place of the calf.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then take the leg with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with your left two fingers.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend it with your left hand, and press the chest of the foot with your right hand without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice as we have told you.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then press the chest of the foot to the thigh in your third finger, and you will pull the calf.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If then it returns to the thigh in one finger, or in two according to this way, and you see the leg equal, it is good: and if not, then you repeat the operation on it, because it returns itself.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If however it is forbidden you the reduction of it with that which we have told you: then make the weak one lie down on its back over its own back over the earth, and fasten a cushion in a firm earth, so that it falls between its legs: and you have already covered over it with a cloth, so that it does not hurt the weak one.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then the assistant takes the chair of it: then extend the assistant's other leg, either with his hands or with a bandage that lies over the collar of the foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then the surgeon extends all his hands against the extension of his opponent's: and a splint is to be stood still between two weak legs, holding it, so that it does not attract the body of his opponent towards the lower parts at the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the surgeon should reduce the dislocation with his hands, and the other should hold a sound leg to the lower parts.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For dislocation returns with violence.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When then the dislocation returns, and you are declared healthy of the recovery thereof: then place the plaster and ointment, and tightly tie it with the firm ligaments, and tie the foot with the ligament to the thigh.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you should beware or fear lest the nerves which are above the heel posterior should be harmed, and the ligament not be placed over them, lest they be injured.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then release it to them in two or three days.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament is softened, tie it up again: then dissolve it on the third or fourth day: and forbid the weak one from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If however he dares to walk before that time, it is not secure that the ligament may not be dissolved over the dislocation, and corrupted, and not receive after that treatment.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If however a hot aposteme happens to him: then it is necessary that you should give him in the sedative of his, in which our narrative precedes in another place from the cure, and ointment, until it be removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	¶ About the dislocation of the toes of the foot, and care.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that he be equal to what is dislocated from them with the extension of a little without labor: and that indeed is not difficult, but rather easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If however the dislocation is in some of the nails of the sole of the foot: then it is necessary that he make his weak foot sit on a place equal to the earth, or on a table: and stand as walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you stand still and place your foot on that which is being discussed from among those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then heat that with your foot while you wait, and you will see it already even, and there will be no sign of an eminence in its place.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under your foot's heel a tablet which will take the whole foot, with two heads on it.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then tighten it accordingly, after three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then loosen it, and make it rest from walking for many days, until it is tightened and secured from reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	¶ About the kinds of dislocations with a bone or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	¶ Head XXXVI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens from that, and you take care of its cure and restoration, death often follows: and therefore it is not proper to presume upon the cure of that kind, unless he who does so be very skilled in the art, having long practice, merciful, pious, slow, not audacious, nor presumptuous: and to use in medicines which are laid up hot only: and to let go the weak for a long time.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you see, or hope for health from the salvation of pain and in which something seems to hope:
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, let him try the reduction of that immediately at the beginning of the case, before the hot aposteme comes.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If then the member returns according to our will, then we administer the regimen which soothes the hot aposteme: and we care for the bone with it that is convenient to him from dry unguents.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	But if the dislocation is with a fracture, and happen in bones that are separated from each other, then let him try the removal of those, and make in it what I said in simple diseases from that which precedes in those places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	According to your virtue, and to keep you safe from the beginning of life to the end of it, fear nothing. This is according to what I have said before.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For this is better for you before God, and more lasting for your glory, and more safe for your body among them at their time.
